indicators.justification:
Emissions data is managed and published by different government agencies. Namely, 'Emission Registration' (1) and the 'Environmental Data Compendium' (2), two platforms by the State Government, datasets by the Dutch Emission Authority published on the national data portal (3), and pages dedicated to emissions data on the open data platform of Statistics Netherlands (CBS) (4). CBS offers interactive tables, bar diagrams and graphs that can be filtered by different types of emissions, time periods and sectors (f.i. total Dutch economy, agriculture, households). The do the same for IPCC greenhouse emissions, per climate sector (industry, farming, mobility, urban areas), per quarter. The data can also be downloaded in CSV- and JSON-format. The Emission Registration database contains almost 100,000,000 emission figures. They offer different ranked lists, and it is possible to create maps and graphs, for different emissions, time periods and sources. The data can also be exported in XLSX. The Environmental Data Compendium offers data figures, visualisations, analytics and fact sheets on different topics. The dataset on Data.government.nl concerns the emissions of CO2 and other greenhouse gases  reported by participants in the European Trading System (EU ETS), so emissions by (large industrial) installations that fall under the scope of these regulations. They can be downloaded in ODS-format for different time periods between 2008-2019. 

All the data from all platforms  is openly licensed (CC-BY 4.0), and available free of charge  in machine-readable formats. Overall, the data seems to be timely and updated. The Emission Registration does not provide any info, but the CBS datasets were updated June 16th 2021, and November 9th 2020, and the data on Data.government.nl on August 4th 2021. The Compendium offers many different products on different themes, which are all published once in a certain time period. Some of their data goes back as far as 1986, and they provide graphs and analyses in which changes are tracked. The CBS and Emission Registration data covers 1990-2019 (and 2019-2020 with regards to the IPCC data). 

The data provides national coverage. It is possible to download data in bulk on the CBS platform, and through an Emission Registration API. (5)  Also, the datasets include detailed information on greenhouse gas emissions and targets reported to the UNFCCC: reports and datasets refer to IPCC methods and requirements abided in the collection and analysis of the data. (6)  

(1) Rijksoverheid, 'Emissieregistratie', http://www.emissieregistratie.nl/erpubliek/bumper.nl.aspx and 'Selectie', http://www.emissieregistratie.nl/erpubliek/erpub/selectie/criteria.aspx.
(2) Rijksoverheid, 'Compendium voor de leefomgeving', https://www.clo.nl/onderwerpen/emissie-naar-lucht-water-en-bodem. 
(3) Data.overheid.nl, 'CO2 Emissiegegevens', https://data.overheid.nl/dataset/co2-emissiegegevens---nederlandse-emissieautoriteit.
(4) CBS Statline, 'Emissies naar lucht door de Nederlandse economie; nationale rekeningen', https://opendata.cbs.nl/statline/#/CBS/nl/dataset/83300NED/table?ts=1627917043233, and CBS Statline, 'Emissies broeikasgassen (IPCC); klimaatsector, kwartaal', https://opendata.cbs.nl/statline/#/CBS/nl/dataset/84979NED/table?ts=1627919282585. 
(5) Emissie Registratie, 'Export',  http://www.emissieregistratie.nl/erpubliek/erpub/export/bron.aspx. 
(6) CBS Statline, 'Emissies van broeikassen berekend volgens IPCC-voorschriften', https://opendata.cbs.nl/statline/portal.html?_la=nl&_catalog=CBS&tableId=70946ned&_theme=231.

indicators.justification:
The government collects and publishes data about endangered plants and animal species, on a national level The Environmental Data Compendium publishes all kinds of data figures, analyses, graph visualisations and fact sheets on biodiversity (71 so far).  For instance mammals, reptiles, amphibians, molluscs, fishes, butterflies, dragonflies, mosses, lichens, and vascular plants from the EU Habitat Directive, and birds from the EU Bird Directive. The data shows numbers and trends between 1992 and 2019 (depending on the dataset). Within some of these indicators there are different subcategories, like hazel mouse, root vole, beaver and otter in mammals. There is no comprehensive list that combines all animal types and all varieties of species within these categories. (1) There is also a Green and Red List aggregated data set, which shows how many animal sorts per category (mammals, reptiles) are safe, vulnerable, endangered, severely endangered, and extinct. (2) All Compendium data is published under an open license and can also be downloaded for free in ODS and XLSX. And each dataset comes with an explanation of where the data comes from, how the data has been collected, and what kind of limitations are apparent with regards to availability and methodology.


Furthermore, On the website for protected species from the Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, there are multiple lists available that all provide Red List information about a certain category of animals. Green List data is available to a certain extent, but also not on a high level of detail. (3) Lastly, Statistics Netherlands (CBS) also has a page in their data portal dedicated to species threatened with extinction (according to the Red List Indicator). It shows the percentage of different species in different years, compared to 1995 (which serves as the starting point of 100 percent). (4) The categories are: amphibians, breeding birds, butterflies, vascular plants, dragonflies, reptiles and mammals (with no subcategories). Is it possible to view the data in a table or graph, and to download it (also in bulk), in HTML, CSV and JSON. So it is machine-readable, and also the data is free of charge and openly licensed (CC BY 4.0). It is updated every year (last on June 16th 2021). (5) 

(1) Compendium voor de Leefomgeving, [search for 'beschermde dieren Nederland'], https://www.clo.nl/search/site/beschermde%20dieren%20nederland?limit=100&stopics%5B0%5D=Biodiversiteit&page=0. 
(2) Compendium voor de leefomgeving, 'Aantal bedreigde en verdwenen soorten in Nederland, per 2020', https://www.clo.nl/indicatoren/nl1052-aantal-bedreigde-planten--en-diersoorten?ond=20882. 
(3) Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, 'Rode lijsten', https://minlnv.nederlandsesoorten.nl/content/rode-lijsten. 
(4) CBS Open Data Statline, 'Rode Lijst Indicator; met uitsterven bedreigde dieren en planten', 
https://opendata.cbs.nl/#/CBS/nl/dataset/82787NED/table?ts=1627922927354. 
(5) CBS Open Data Statline, 'Rode Lijst Indicator; met uitsterven bedreigde dieren en planten. Tabeltoelichting & tabelinformatie', 
https://opendata.cbs.nl/portal.html?_la=nl&_catalog=CBS&tableId=82787NED&_theme=224.

indicators.justification:
There is climate vulnerability data available online, but the government provides it in different bits and pieces (through watwer boards, provinces and municipalities): there is no complete and comprehensive open dataset available that provides insight into climate vulnerability and adaptation. The platform 'Climate Effect Atlas' offers interactive maps of the country, which 'can be used to gain a picture of the physical consequences of climate change in an area, and how this will impact residents and the environment'. However, this platform was developed by research institutions (like Wageningen University) and is managed by Climate Adaptation Services (CAS). This organisation does work with the governmental  Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute (KNMI), plus in 2020  the Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management commissioned CAS to update and expand the Climate Impact Atlas. So there the government does promote the availability of climate adaptation information though this platform, but cannot be deemed the result of government action. (1)  Also, this platform offers great insight into and access to the information through visualisation (in maps), but it is only possible to download PDFs of the maps through the 'printer' option. Soon it will be possible to request GIS files with the geographical data, through a form, but this is not yet available. As soon as it is, this data will be public: it is an open platform. 

Currently, the data is available as ArcGIS Online content via the ArcGIS website. This makes it possible for example, to use the data in a GIS framework without having to download it. However, this still means it is not possible for anyone to download open, machine-readable datasets. And Esri NL publishes the datasets of ArcGIs with terms of use: for instance, it is mandatory to include copyright references, it is not allowed to distribute the data or use it in navigation systems, et cetera. (2) The Atlas data is based on KNMIs climate scenarios, which are defined on IPCC's data and models. (3) 

The data contains information on everything from future natural hazards, to extreme weather events and climate variability. The Climate Effect Atlas main map can be filtered on different themes: waterlogging, flooding, drought, and heat. Also, there are different 'map layers' with different boxes that can be checked to show them on the map: climate change (f.i. amount of days above 20/25/30 degrees, amount of frost and snow days, days with more than 15/25 mm of rain), physical consequences (f.i. risk of heating surface water and shortages, wildfire susceptibility, land subsidence 2020-2100), sectoral impacts (f.i. urban areas, lonely elderly people, risk of rotting building foundations, flood impact reduction opportunities) and basic maps (f.i. percentage of paving per neighborhood, types of landscape). (4) Furthermore, the platform offers 'map narratives': these provide background information to the main maps. They tell you what you see on the maps and help you to set to work with the information. In addition, the map narratives provide a basis for potential solution strategies.' In other words, they explain the different categories, topics and filters. (5) 

The website is updated several times a year, with new maps being added. In between, minor adjustments are made. If new KNMI climate scenarios are available, a large-scale update will take place because this affects many maps. New KNMI scenarios are expected in 2023. The data draws on granular local information. The maps have been developed using national data: the results provide a picture at regional scale and are usually rough and indicative at a local level. At the national level, the maps represent the best data that is publicly available. The scale level of the data differs per map layer. Maps with statistics, such as the number of tropical days or precipitation deficit, show differences at the national level. Other maps, such as the wind chill heat map, are more detailed. Since the Atlas is based on national data, in many cases, it is possible to find more detailed data at the regional and local levels. For instance, many district water boards have conducted detailed analyses of their territory and more detailed information may also be made available by provincial and municipal authorities. (6) 

(1) Klimaateffectatlas, 'FAQ', https://www.klimaateffectatlas.nl/en/faq, and CAS, 'About us', https://www.climateadaptationservices.com/en/about-us/. 
(2)  Klimaateffectatlas, 'FAQ', https://www.klimaateffectatlas.nl/en/faq and Esri NL, 'Overview', ArcGIS, https://www.arcgis.com/home/group.html?id=72cf4ad575d443de8e2a6acd0ece60aa#overview, and EsriNL, 'Terms of Use', ArcGIS, https://www.esri.nl/nl-nl/legal/voorwaarden/esri-nederland-terms-of-use?rmedium=www_esri_nl&rsource=%2Foverig%2Fterms-of-use. 
(3) Archiefweb, 'KNMI Projects',  https://knmiprojects.archiefweb.eu/?subsite=klimaatscenarios#archive. 
(4) Klimaateffectatlas, 'Viewer', https://www.klimaateffectatlas.nl/en/. 
(5) Klimaateffectatlas, 'Map narratives, https://www.klimaateffectatlas.nl/en/map-narratives. 
(6) Klimaateffectatlas, 'FAQ', https://www.klimaateffectatlas.nl/en/faq.

indicators.justification:
There is no legal requirement for published company data to be 'open', in the sense that it should be free of rights, free of costs and published according to open standards. (1) The Chamber of Commerce (KvK) is responsible for keeping and supplying the register with Ultimate Beneficial Owners (UBO). Through the KvK-website, it is possible to download company extracts from the register, in PDF-format, but only for a fee of €2,50 each. (2) So, no bulk data is available. Also, users need to register first. Additionally, there is an API that can be used to search the KvK database by company name or KvK-registration number, using a UBO-register filter, but it is not possible to search by a person's name. (3) This makes it hard to discover people who have conflicting interests, whilst preventing corruption is supposedly a main goal of the register. Lastly, the data is provided in Dutch. So overall, the accessibility of the data is quite restricted. As for the use of the data, it is not openly licensed. Nine restrictions are stipulated in the terms of use, based on database rights. Two examples: The Customer may only use the Trade Register data, including the UBO-data, in a manner that is not in conflict with laws and regulations, nor does it infringe the rights of KVK or third parties. The Customer is obliged to prevent the use of Trade Register data giving the impression that the customer performs the statutory tasks assigned to the Chamber of Commerce. (4)

The following UBO-data is publicly available (after payment and registration, with user restrictions): first and last name, month of birth and year of birth, nationality, country of residence, and the nature and size of the interest that a UBO has within an organization (for instance: shareholder, 25%). For certain authorities empowered by law, like investigative bodies, and for The Financial Intelligence Unit, banks or other Wwft (anti-corruption and -terrorism) institutions with a financial task, all information is accessible, so also the personal data that is not made available to others. (5) The obligation for legal entities in the Netherlands to register their UBO's within the Company Register, was created on September 27th, 2020, when the Implementation Act entered into force. The time that existing companies were given to register, was 18 months - so they have until end of May 2022. Because of this term, a lot information is still missing. At the beginning of June 2021, the register contained 209.403 entries. (6) It should be noted that this survey only covers the period up to May 1st, so it cannot be said with certainty how many entries there were at that time. The obligation to register applies to all economic sectors. However, it does not apply to all types of companies, for instance not to sole proprietorships, listed limited liability companies (BVs) and public limited liability companies (NVs), some associations, et cetera. (7) 

(1) Handelsregisterwet, 2007, Chapter 4: De verstrekking en het gebruik van gegevens, https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0021777/2020-12-04#Hoofdstuk4. 
(2) KvK, 'Kvk Uitreksel UBO-register', https://www.kvk.nl/producten-bestellen/bedrijfsproducten-bestellen/uittreksel-ubo-register/.
(3) KvK, 'Zoek bedrijf', https://www.kvk.nl/bestellen/#/?productfilter=ubo. 
(4) KvK, 'Gebruikersvoorwaarden', https://www.kvk.nl/over-kvk/over-het-handelsregister/toegang-handelsregister/aanvraag-toegangscode/gebruiksvoorwaarden/. 
(5) Handelsregisterwet, 2007, Chapter 5: Verstrekking van gegevens aan bestuursorganen en andere bevoegde autoriteiten en gebruik van gegevens door bestuursorganen, Article 28 paragraph 2, https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0021777/2020-12-04#Hoofdstuk5, and Handelsregisterbesluit, 2008, Chapter 8: Verstrekking van gegevens, Article 51a, https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0024067/2021-04-30#Hoofdstuk8. 
(6) Hoekstra, 2021, 'Beantwoording kamervragen over het UBO-register' (letter from the minister of Finance to the House of Representatives), https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/documenten/kamerstukken/2021/06/29/beantwoording-kamervragen-over-het-ubo-register. 
(7) KvK, 26 May 2021,'De belangrijkste vragen over het UBO-register', https://www.kvk.nl/advies-en-informatie/top-5/de-belangrijkste-vragen-over-het-ubo-register/.

indicators.justification:
The Trade Register (Handelsregister) is the basic register, in which all companies, legal entities and other organizations participating in economic activity, are listed. The responsibility for maintaining and publishing the company information, lies with the Chamber of Commerce (KvK), a commercial institution. The KvK sells different 'products', datasets, for each company. An 'extract' contains the most important company information, inter alia, the following: it's KvK-number (a unique company identifier), trade name(s), the start, continuation or end date, information about the person(s) to whom it belongs, and the location(s). (1) It tells users who they are dealing with, who is authorized to sign, and whether there has been a bankruptcy. (2) The KvK also sells other products, like the statutes, annual reports, terms of use and historical data of companies, and for instance address files tailored to specific branch or region. 
 
There is no legal requirement for published company data, including UBO-data, to be 'open', in the sense that it should be free of rights, free of costs and published according to open standards. (3) The Chamber of Commerce (Kamer van Koophandel, KvK), which is responsible for the maintaining and publicizing of company information, (4) publishes the register online, where it is possible to search by trade name, KvK-number, address and type of legal entity. To access more information, the user then has to register himself through an account, and pay a fee, the level of which depends how much information and what type of data he is requesting. The main company information extract costs €7,70, and is provided in PDF-format. (5) The KvK also publishes a weekly updated Trade Register Open Data Set on its website, with anonymized, so not complete, company data. It can be downloaded in a machine-readable CSV-format. (6) Apart from this dataset, only the yearly accounts of micro, small and medium legal entities are provided in a machine-readable format: XBRL, a digital file of code that can be entered into a software program. However, this data is not 'open': a file costs €7,70. Also, KvK offers a standardized, so more structured but not machine-readable version of the accounts of all companies for €3,15. These HTML-files contain the balance sheet and profit and loss account, as filed by the company, in a standard format, making it easy to compare the figures or different years or companies. (7) 

None of the company data is openly licenced. Terms of Use apply to all information in the Trade Register. There are nine restrictions, based on database rights. Two examples: The Customer may only use the Trade Register data, including the UBO-data, in a manner that is not in conflict with laws and regulations, nor does it infringe the rights of KVK or third parties. The Customer is obliged to prevent the use of Trade Register data giving the impression that the customer performs the statutory tasks assigned to the Chamber of Commerce. (8)

The trade register can be searched through this API: https://www.kvk.nl/zoeken/handelsregister/.  Users can purchase products related to the companies they find through this API. Also, there is a KvK-API:  a connection between a users software application and the Trade Register, for a monthly fee of €5,15, plus €0,016 per data request. The connection can be made through the KvK's developer portal. (9) 

 (1) Handelsregisterwet 2007, Chapter 2: Het handelsregister, Section 2.2: Inhoud handelsregister, Article 9, https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0021777/2020-12-04#Hoofdstuk2. 
(2) KvK, 'Over het handelsregister', https://www.kvk.nl/over-kvk/over-het-handelsregister/.
(3) Handelsregisterwet, 2007, Chapter 4: De verstrekking en het gebruik van gegevens, https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0021777/2020-12-04#Hoofdstuk4.
(4) Handelsregisterwet, 2007, Chapter 2: Het handelsregister, Section 2.1: Instellen handelsregister, Articles 3 and 4, https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0021777/2020-12-04.
(5) Financiële regeling handelsregister 2019, Articles 1, 2 and 3, https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0042721/2021-01-01.
(6) KvK, 'KvK Handelsregister Open Data Set', https://www.kvk.nl/producten-bestellen/koppeling-handelsregister/kvk-handelsregister-open-data-set/
(7) KvK, 'Jaarrekeningen', https://www.kvk.nl/producten-bestellen/bedrijfsproducten-bestellen/jaarrekeningen/. 
(8) KvK, 'Gebruikersvoorwaarden', https://www.kvk.nl/over-kvk/over-het-handelsregister/toegang-handelsregister/aanvraag-toegangscode/gebruiksvoorwaarden/. 
(9)KvK, 'KVK API',  https://www.kvk.nl/producten-bestellen/koppeling-handelsregister/kvk-api/.

indicators.justification:
Civil registration and vital statistics (CRVS) information is made available as open data through government actions. According to the Civil Code, the Ministry of Justice and Security is responsible for policies for the civil registration process at a national level, while individual municipalities are responsible for registering vital events and maintaining records. Information from each registration record is entered in the population register of the municipality. The Basic Registration of Persons (BRP) Act designated the Ministry of the Interior for the task to maintain a central population register (the BRP) that  contains and synchronizes all personal records from all municipalities daily.

The National Office for Identity Data (Rvig) is responsible for overseeing the BRP data-sharing process and data quality (and for instance managing travel document systems), but CRVS data can be accessed through the open data platform of Statistics Netherlands (CBS). CBS has been authorized to receive all data required to compile population statistics, including vital statistics. This is in line with requirements and standards from the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (UN DESA), Eurostat, and the Council of Europe. (1)

CBS has developed a Dashboard population data dashboard with the most basic population facts, figures and visualisation. Via this dashboard you can also access underlying datasets with specific data regarding mortality, genders and age distribution, households, life expectancy, average life cycle, and migration. (2) Apart from this dashboard, CBS offers lots of different datasets, which all provide information on a specific topic within a category (like mortality and birth) through interactive tables (which can be filtered), graphs and the possibly the download the raw data. 

In publishing cause of death information, the World Health Organization guidelines are used (where possible) to classify and code causes of death. Coding of the data happens automatically with IRIS, which is "an automated, interactive mortality coding software system, which codes multiple causes of death and selects the underlying cause of death for statistical tabulation." (3) IRIS is
based upon the international death certificate form that the WHO provides in Volume 2 of ICD-10, meaning the causes of death are coded following ICD-10 rules. This makes the data fully interoperable. (4) All the causes of death, per 100.000 people, per year, can be found in a CBS dataset about health, lifestyle, health care use and case of death (from 1900). (5) The amount of deaths per region per month, can be found in a CBS dataset about population development. (6) And specific information about the amount of deaths per demographic (age category) per year in the country dan be found in another dataset. (7) 

Birth information is also distributed over different datasets. There is one  with key figures, like the amount of life births and stillbirths, boys and girls, single and multiple births, and the average mother and father age (from 1950). (8) There is also a map with data providing insight into the amount of births and deaths per municipality, (9) and a  table dataset that contains the amount of life births in the most recent months, which can be filtered for every municipality, province and country section. (10) Furthermore, there is a dataset showing the amount and average amount of births by women with Dutch or migration backgrounds. (11) There is no data about the educational attainment of mothers, or the usual place of residence of parents. There is also no information available in any dataset about live-birth order and interval between last and previous live births to mother,  gestational age, birth weight, place and month of birth registration, site of delivery, attendant at birth, and month in which prenatal care began.

Like all CBS-data, the CRSV-datasets are openly licensed under the CC BY 4.0 licence and available free of charge. Also, each dataset can be downloaded in a machine-readable CSV-format.
Data is continually updated, but how frequently depends on each dataset, but all of them have been updated this month or the one before. And the 'population counter' on the population dashboard is real time: it shows how many people are born and deceased every few seconds.  Historical changes in the data can be tracked: Each dataset provides data per year or per period and the start and end dates differ. The data does not include information on data limitations, specifically on the completeness of vital statistics in different provinces, counties, or regions of the country.

indicators.justification:
Some data about the capacity of the healthcare system is made available as open data (without mentioning any specific license) by the government. This has only been the case since the Covid-19 crisis started and it concerns only Coid-related capacity information. There is a platform that provides insights into the capacity (hospital beds, IC primarily) on Zorg-capaciteit.nl, but this website provides this data only after registration, which is only available to those who work in the healthcare system. (1) There are some public websites that provide information regarding the capacity of the healthcare system on different levels and over time. For instance,  Zorginzicht.nl/openbare-data hand Opendisdata.nl. However, this data is not real time. 

The Corona Dashboard set up by the government does include current data regarding new hospital and IC admissions, but only  in relation to COVID-19, and this data does not say anything about the maximum capacity. (2) The dashboard also provides information about vaccinations: mostly about the number of administered vaccinations, but also the available stock. (3) The Dashboard data is updated twice a week, so not technically real-time but quite current. The hospital admission data is available as open data (CSV, JSON), the vaccination capacity data is not. (4)  Furthermore, there is the National Coordination Centre for Patient Distribution, which was established at the quest of the Ministry of Health - so not by the government itself - by National Network Acute Care, a network organisation consisting of the eleven Dutch hospitals that have a trauma center. They provide a 'live URL', which is updated once a day monday through friday, and through which data set in CSV-format can be downloaded that contains national figures on the amount of clinic beds occupied by Covid-patients, ICU-beds occupied by patients with and without Covid, and the number of new admissions to the IC and clinics. (4) Even though the Dashboard and the Live URl only contain Covid-related capacity information with regards to hospital beds, the data still says something about the general capacity of these hospitals. However, as mentioned before, the data only contains the number of occupied beds, which does not give any information about the maximum capacity. Alle the platforms and datasets that have been mentioned, provide data on a national level, so there is no information about individual hospitals. 

(1) Zorgcapaciteit, https://www.zorg-capaciteit.nl/beddencapaciteit/index.jsp. 
(2) Rijksoverheid, 'Intensive care-opnames', Coronadashboard, https://coronadashboard.rijksoverheid.nl/landelijk/intensive-care-opnames. 
(3) Rijksoverheid, 'COVID-19-vaccinaties', Coronadashboard, https://coronadashboard.rijksoverheid.nl/landelijk/vaccinaties, 
(4) Rijksoverheid, 'Verantwoording', Coronadashboard,  https://coronadashboard.rijksoverheid.nl/verantwoording, and RIVM, 'Covid-19 ziekenhuisopnames (volgens NICE registratie) per gemeente per ziekenhuisopnamedatum en meldingsdatum', https://data.rivm.nl/meta/srv/dut/catalog.search#/metadata/4f4ad069-8f24-4fe8-b2a7-533ef27a899f?tab=general.  
(5) LCPS, 'Actuele data COVID-bezetting', https://lcps.nu/datafeed/.

indicators.justification:
Land tenure data is made available by the Cadastre, a government organisation. It is part of the Land Registry: 'ownership information' is one of the products the organisation offers. Each data extract (which consists of the information of one house or land parcel), contains information on: who is the owner, who may use all or part of the property,  what restrictions apply to the use (for example, whether the property is a monument), what the surface area is (not with flats) and the sales price from the last deed of sale, and in case of mortgage, the amount (if these numbers are known). Individual owners (natural persons) are identified by the following information: gender (Mr/Mrs), first and last name, residential address, date and place of birth, and civil (marital) state. The information is based on another basic registry: the Personal Records Database (BRP). When the owner is a legal entity, the company information extract of the registry contains the company name, legal form, KvK-number, and address.  The beneficial ownership of land within a company is not registered. However, it is registered with respect to both individuals and companies, which type of (limited) right every rightholder has, like property right burdened with a lease, emphyteusis, right of emphyteusis, right of superficies, usufruct, etc. The registry also contains the share to which someone is entitled (f.i. 1/2). (1)

The data covers all land parcels in the country, which can be found through the Kadaster-API, by entering an address or postal code: https://www.kadaster.nl/. Then the user can choose 5 different products for this parcel: extracts from the data he can buy. They are: 'Ownership information', 'Purchase price information', 'Mortgage information', 'House report', and 'Cadastral map'.
A parcel is a piece of land of which the Land Registry has measured the boundaries and which has been assigned its own number. The Cadastre does not have addresses for land plots without buildings, such as agricultural land, building plots or green spaces, but they do provide the tenure information on these land. (2) The data covers every type of land, so also for instance farm land and state land (which, according to article 5:24 of the Dutch Civil Code, also includes every piece of land that does not have an owner). (3) Every extract of ownership information of a certain parcel, contains its coordinates. These are RD-coordinates: State triangle coordinates. (4) But to assess the position of a parcel, the product 'Cadastral map' can be downloaded (bought). The cadastral map shows the overall location of a cadastral parcel in its vicinity. On the map, you can see the cadastral parcel boundaries, parcel numbers and the most important buildings, among other things. (5) 

The main barriers to accessibility and usability are  the terms of use, the pay barrier and the closed file format. For every extract of ownership data, a product needs to be bought. The data cannot be accessed without paying 2,95 for each extract, so per parcel. Furthermore, every product is only offered in pdf-format, so the data is not machine-readable. Lastly, the data is not openly licensed. When a Land Registry product is received, the pdf-file states: 'With regard to the cadastral information, the Land Registry and the Public Registers Service, reserves the right as referred to in Article 2 paragraph 1 in conjunction with Article 6 paragraph 3 of the Databases Act.' (6) Article 2 paragraph 1 of this Act gives the owner of a database the sole right to give others permission to reuse the data. (7) The Kadaster has established terms of use, in which (under '6. usage rights'), it determines for example 'Personal data provided by the Land Registry may not be used by the customer in derived products or services with a commercial (profit-oriented) purpose.' (8)

The Kadaster register is continually updated, because new deeds and documents are continuously provided to complete new registrations and change existing ones. However, different types of information take different amounts of time (hours, days, weeks) to be processed. (9) If users want to request historical data about previous owners of a parcel to track changes of time, this costs at least €73.50 euros. (10)  For people or organisations carrying out research with an historical purpose however, it is possible to use the Kadaster archives for free. (11) 

It is always possible that government registrations are missing required data. Land ownership and the rights to a piece of land constantly change, and as stated before it can take time to process changes, or landowners and rights holders can omit to report changes. When users (governments or citizens) want to report changes or a suspected mistake in the registry, they can submit a notification via a digital form. (12)  Government agencies even have a legal obligation to do this. (13). 

(1) Kadaster, 'Eigendomsinformatie', https://www.kadaster.nl/producten/woning/eigendomsinformatie, Kadaster, 'Eigendoms informatio productvoorbeeld' (product example of an ownership information extract), https://www.kadaster.nl/documents/1953498/2032714/Eigendomsinformatie+productvoorbeeld.pdf/94853973-7b55-ea04-25a4-18b8a383143e?t=1538572036626, and Cadastre Act ('Kadasterwet'), 1989, Chapter 3, Title 1, Article 48,  https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0004541/2021-07-01#Hoofdstuk8. 
(2) Kadaster, 'Brief (kennisgeving) ontvangen', https://kadasterservice.nl/eigenaar-landbouwgrond-opzoeken. 
(3) Civil Code ('Burgerlijk Wetboek'), Book 5, Title 3, Article 24. 
(4) Kadaster, 'Eigendoms informatio productvoorbeeld' (product example of an ownership information extract), https://www.kadaster.nl/documents/1953498/2032714/Eigendomsinformatie+productvoorbeeld.pdf/94853973-7b55-ea04-25a4-18b8a383143e?t=1538572036626. 
(5) Kadaster, 'Kadastrale kaart', https://www.kadaster.nl/producten/woning/kadastrale-kaart
(6) Kadaster, 'Eigendomsinformatie', https://www.kadaster.nl/producten/woning/eigendomsinformatie, and Kadaster, 'Eigendoms information productvoorbeeld' (product example of an ownership information extract), https://www.kadaster.nl/documents/1953498/2032714/Eigendomsinformatie+productvoorbeeld.pdf/94853973-7b55-ea04-25a4-18b8a383143e?t=1538572036626
(7) Databank Act ('Databankenwet'), 1999, Article 2,  https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0010591/2021-06-07. 
(8) Kadaster, 'Algemene leveringsvoorwaarden', https://www.kadaster.nl/algemene-leveringsvoorwaarden. 
(9) Kadaster, 'Hoe actueel zijn de registraties van het Kadaster?', https://www.kadaster.nl/-/hoe-actueel-zijn-de-registraties-van-het-kadaster-. 
(10) Kadaster, 'Vroegere eigenaren opvragen', https://www.kadaster.nl/producten/akte-en-onderzoek/vroegere-eigenaren-opvragen, and other historical products can be found here: Kadaster, 'Onderzoek in de openbare registers', https://www.kadaster.nl/producten/akte-en-onderzoek/onderzoek-in-de-openbare-registers. 
(11) Kadaster, 'Historisch onderzoek', https://www.kadaster.nl/situaties/onderwijs-en-studie/historisch-onderzoek. 
(12) Kadaster, 'Klacht indienen', https://formulieren.kadaster.nl/klacht-indienen. 
(13) Ministry of Interior Affairs and Kingdom Relations, 'Basisregistratie topografie', https://www.geobasisregistraties.nl/basisregistraties/topografie.

indicators.justification:
In the Netherlands all budget and spending data regarding the national government is published on a central website (1). On this platform almost all financial information that undergoes public scrutiny by the House of Parliament is publicly available. The 'Miljoenennota' which describes the economic and financial situation in the country, expected future developments and the most important plans, costs and implications for the coming year is available.  The 'Rijksbegroting', stating the budget allocated to each
Ministry and their expected expenses is published alongside this Miljoenennota. Unfortunately the enacted budget is not published as a whole, but rather is made available through graphics visualising government spending en income. The 'Voorjaarsnota', 'Najaarsnota' together form the in-year budget reports and mid-year reports, and the so-called 'Rijksjaarverslag' that contains annual financial reports of all ministries are also published on this website. The 'Rijksjaarverslag' needs to be audited and approved by the National Audit Institute before it is presented to the House of Parliament. 

Next to presenting these documents on this website many of the financial information is also published as open data (2). These open datasets which are organised according to the formats provided in the 'Rijksbegrotingsvoorschriften' contain the public information that is also sent to the House of Representatives in the official documents, highlighting the budget figures through visualisation and making them trackable over time (3). Data is presented in different formats, is free of charge, openly licensed according CC-0 and also accessible via an API (4). One of the biggest issues is that there is no data or information available regarding public budgets and spending on the most disaggregated level: transactions. Additionally, the open datasets in most cases  do not use common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data, or identifiers that can be used to connect budget data to major projects and procurement processes. The open datasets are checked by the team behind Rijksfinancien.nl before publication, responsibility for the content lies with the ministries (3).

(1) https://www.rijksfinancien.nl/
(2) https://www.rijksfinancien.nl/open-data/overzicht-datasets
(3) https://www.rijksfinancien.nl/open-data-0
(4) https://www.rijksfinancien.nl/open-data/api-documentatie

indicators.justification:
In the Netherlands information regarding interest and asset declaration information civil servants is not available. Data regarding ancillary functions, interests/income, gifts and foreign travel expensenses of members of parliament are published (1) twice a year. But because these Code of Conducts mentions that members of parliament are not sanctioned in case of noncompliance, much information is not provided. Research of Zembla shows that 21 members of parliament have ancillary functions that according to this Code of Conduct should have been registered, but in practice weren't (2) The most recent GRECO report therefore also recommended the Netherlands to develop a coordinated strategy for the integrity of persons entrusted with top executive functions, information should be made easily accessible to the public and that this code should be go hang in hand with a mechanism of sanctions and supervision (3). Also data regarding ancillary functions, interests, gifts and foreign travel expensenses of members of local councils are published on the websites of their respective municipalities. Example of this is provided in the attached document (4).

Registers regarding ancillary positions of Ministers, MPs are available https://www.tweedekamer.nl/kamerleden_en_commissies/openbare_registers
Registers regarding ancillary positions of members of local councils are published on the websites of their respective municipalities, provinces. Transparency International's Integrity Watch publishes this data in a user friendly way (5).

indicators.justification:
In 2012 the House of Representatives in the Netherlands introduced a Lobbyist Register. It comprises around 110 lobbyists who have a permanent pass for parliamentary entry. Lobbyists can voluntarily request such a permanent access pass. The access pass gives the holder access to the parliamentary premises to contact MPs, to attend public meetings and to consult documents. The Register contains around 110 lobbyists who have this permanent pass. The register, which is publicly available on the House of Representatives' website (1), is voluntary, regularly updated and outlines the name, company and actor for which the lobbying is done. However, the actual number of lobbyists present in the Hague however, is believed to be in the thousands. Certain civil society organizations are providing lobby data in the Netherlands to increase the transparency of lobbying. For example the tool open-lobby by the Open State Foundation provides insight into all the agendas of ministers and state secretaries with external organisations (2). Although this scraped data is far from complete it shows that 26,6% of the reported appointments are with companies, 20% with business representatives and 7,8% with civil society organisations (3). The most recent GRECO report also states that the Netherlands needs to prioritise the development of legislation regarding the collection and publication of lobby data to meet transparency standards (4).  

(1) https://www.tweedekamer.nl/contact_en_bezoek/lobbyisten
(2) https://openstate.eu/nl/openlobby/#tool
(3) https://www.volkskrant.nl/nieuws-achtergrond/onderzoek-naar-transparantie-bij-overheid-grote-bedrijven-onevenredig-vaak-op-de-koffie-bij-de-minister~bd29bda0/
(4) https://rm.coe.int/fifth-evaluation-round-preventing-corruption-and-promoting-integrity-i/1680931c9d

indicators.justification:
Political party finance and campaign finance data is published by the ministry of Internal Affairs on rijksoverheid.nl on three different pages/urls: one for overviews of gifts and liabilities to political parties and their secondary institutions (1), for overviews of gifts and liabilities of political parties in relation to parliamentary election campaigns (2) and for annual financial reports of political parties (3). These datasets are available free of charge, annual reports are published as PDFs, all other data in XLS format. There is no explicit mention of the licenses of these datasets, the data is not (yet) published on data.overheid.nl, the national open data platform. The data is organised per year, no full dataset (per category) with historical data is available and is available from 2016 onwards. While data regarding the finance of political campaigns is up-to-date, the most recent financial reports stem from 2019. 

Although political parties are required to provide all information, in practice this is not always the case. A report from the Commission 'toezicht financiën politieke partijen' showed that for the elections of 2021 three parties didn't  provide any information at all, five did not provide complete information, and 18 parties didn't provide the information in time (4).  Dutch political parties are perfectly aware of the loopholes in the legal framework regarding the financing of political parties. A recent study of the newspaper de Telegraaf (4) in which a journalist posed as an entrepreneur seeking to donate €15.000 to various political parties on the condition of him remaining anonymous. As earlier mentioned this donation of €15.000 is well over the maximum amount of a total of €4.500 in which individuals can remain anonymous. Only four parties (Socialist Party, Party for Animals, Forum for Democracy and the Party for Freedom) didn't recommend illegal activities or ways to utilize the loopholes in Netherlands legislation. While multiple parties recommended the entrepreneur to spread the donation over multiple years, one party (50Plus) advised the donor to send the money in cash to a party employee. 

(1) https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/documenten/jaarverslagen/2020/10/08/overzichten-financiering-politieke-partijen-2019
(2) https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/documenten/publicaties/2021/03/10/overzicht-giften-en-schulden-politieke-partijen-tweede-kamerverkiezingen-2021-van-2019-tot-en-met-24-februari-2021
(3) https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/documenten/publicaties/2019/10/25/financiele-verslagen-over-2018-van-politieke-partijen
(4) https://www.tweedekamer.nl/kamerstukken/brieven_regering/detail?id=2020Z24956&did=2020D52401
(5)https://www.telegraaf.nl/nieuws/2123264497/politieke-partijen-open-voor-schimmige-donaties

indicators.justification:
There is no central platform or database in the Netherlands that collects and publishes information of legitimate wob requests, let alone as open data. No percentage is tracked of requests, duration of handling requests, details about material withheld and the reasons for withholding it are available in one place. Public institutions do have their own practices regarding the publication of publishing documents that need to be publicly available after successful wob-requests. The central government publishes the wob-requests on their website (1) and covid related wob requests on another  website (2). These websites provide insight into individual wob-records with the requested information attached. Although ministries have agreed that as of 1 January 2017 all Wob decisions, i.e. allocations (requested information is made public) and rejections (requested information is not made public), will be published on the aforementioned webpages. However this is far from standard practice and widely adopted by public bodies. Since the COVID-crisis, the ministry of Health and Welfare has applied an "alternative method" for corona-related wob requests. Instead of assessing every wob request submitted at a time, as it should be done according to the law, the ministry decides when it will disclose which documents about COVID-19 (3).

(3) https://nos.nl/nieuwsuur/artikel/2387051-rechter-wijst-alternatieve-werkwijze-wob-verzoeken-vws-af

indicators.justification:
In the Netherlands public consultation information is public on a central government website (1). This website provides information about legislation and regulations that are being prepared by the cabinet or parliament and that are consulted on the internet. Due to the non-binding character of the current framework and the fact that all ministries are responsible for adequate and effective deployment of the internet consultation instrument, not all legislation goes through public consultation. When public consultation is used as an instrument in most cases all information e.g. notices of intent, reasoned responses, final regulations and justifications are published (timely) (2).   Data is available via API. Also a rest interface of internetconsultatie.nl makes it possible to display publications of new consultations on other websites. The rest interface provides the information about consultations in the form of XML. In this way, external websites can determine their own layout and layout. It is possible to filter this data per department by placing the abbreviation of the desired department at the end of the URL.

(1) https://www.internetconsultatie.nl/
(2) https://rulemaking.worldbank.org/en/data/explorecountries/netherlands
(3) www.internetconsultatie.nl/rest/openconsultaties/

indicators.justification:
In the Netherlands public procurement data and information is fragmented over various platforms and websites. There is one central platform, Tenderned, that publishes all tender announcements of market consultations, advance notices, contract notices, rectifications, and contract award notices (1). Tenderned is a public and open platform that also provides overviews of all tender announcements per half year in XML and accessible via an API. You can keep track of new tender announcements via an RSS API or email notifications.
Often announcement platforms called Tsenders are used to publish information regarding announcements. In those cases a link is provided on Tenderned to the specific announcement and underlying documents. But many of these platforms are not open to the public and only accessible after registration with a unique company identifier (2). As a consequence much of the data regarding the first stages of a public procurement (planning, tendering) are not available to a broader audience. 

Regarding other categories of public procurement information. The ministry of Internal Affairs publishes an overview of all public contracts each 3 months as a PDF (3). Only the most recent overviews are published on this website and historical overviews and data is not available. In addition, no detailed public contract information (payments and transactions, timelines and progress updates, service delivery agreements, performance, etc.) is published in the Netherlands. Spend data and information is also only available in its most aggregated form. This means that annual overviews of which companies have received which contracts are available in CSV format. What makes this information hard to use is that instead of publishing the total or individual contract values per company, information is presented in gradient scales (4).

In respect to all public procurement phases the information and data that is provided (in whatever way) is incomplete e.g. missing data fields and/or incorrect e.g. budgets and or contract values are not filled in correctly, reference numbers are missing, etc. For example, contract and tender values are €1 or €0,01 where these values are not correct. Desk research shows that in 2020 for 68% of all tenders no values or incorrect values of €1, €2, €3, €4 have been published (5). The aggregated contract data that is available consists of many empty data fields which makes the information hard to use for many purposes.  This is confirmed by research under various (re)users of public procurement data in the Netherlands (6).

(1) https://www.tenderned.nl/cms/over-tenderned/tenderned-en-andere-aanbestedingssystemen#
(2) https://platform.negometrix.com/Registration.aspx
(3) https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/documenten/publicaties/2018/12/06/rijkscontracten
(4) https://data.overheid.nl/en/dataset/totaaloverzicht-inkoopdata-rijksoverheid-2018
(5) Dataset TenderNed 2020: https://www.tenderned.nl/cms/over-tenderned/aankondigingen-analyseren-en-downloaden#aankondigingen-analyseren-en-downloaden
(6) https://openstate.eu/nl/2021/05/open-inkoop-in-beeld-presentatie-van-eindrapport-eerste-fase/

indicators.justification:
The government's strategy with regards to promoting dating use, is set out in different instruments. First of all, the Digitalisation Strategy. A large part of this strategy is about sharing and using data, for economic growth and  solving societal issues. A lot of the initiatives mentioned in this strategy are platforms and partnerships,  solicited by the government, which promote and encourage data reuse to improve products, services, et cetera. It promotes reuse by governments as well as economic sectors, health care et cetera. They have been extensively discussed under the third question of the Governance indicator. (1)

Then there is NL DIGITAL: Data Agenda Government, which has also been discussed earlier. Three of it's five elements aim at improving society, transparency and public service through a data-driven way of working within government: 'solving societal issues with data-driven working' (element 1) , 'collecting and sharing knowledge about data-driven working' (element 4), and 'investing in people, organisation and culture change' (developing skills). (2) 

Third, there is the Action Plan Open Government 2020-2022. This action plan is carried out as part of the Netherlands' membership of the Open Government Partnership. It translates the government's vision on transparency and open data into concrete action points and projects. The Ministry of Interior Affairs, and the Learning and Expertise Point Open Government that the Ministry created, are responsible for the action plan. They assigned different governments, public organisations  and civil society organizations to carry out different elements of the plan. A lot of the action points focus on making data open and available, but some of them aim at improving and promoting the reuse of the data. Take for example, V.9 'Open Contract Register'. (3) Together with NGO Open State Foundation and the Chief State Procurement Officer, the ministry is developing an open procurement register, but this data is only valuable when it is being reused by government, companies and journalists, so they have carried out extensive research into the needs of different user groups. (4) Another example: the goal of VI.10 'Open Data Communities' is to match government data supply to the demand from different user groups (individuals, organisations, experts), and to teach them how to reuse data through these communities, by offering examples and the possibility to consult experts. The communities are realised through Data.government.nl. (5) 

Data.government.nl  is the national data portal where all governments are encouraged to publish their datasets as open data, and where re-users can search and filter this data within different themes. It has been discussed extensively as part of earlier questions (f.i. the previous). The portal encourages data re-use by showcasing high-value data sets, impact stories and statistics, case studies and applications made with government data, et cetera. (6). Also, they host a growing number of data communities: groups of data owners, users and experts within a specific domain, like education, social security or energy. The communities offer in-depth information, specific data, reference data, applications and an opportunity to directly ask questions to experts. (7) Lastly, on it's support-page, Data.government.nl offers three types of information, on 'open data', 'publishing data' and 'using data'. The support for data use they offer consist of f.i. tips on how to search for datasets, information about different file formats in which the data is offered, and the possibility to admit requests for needed data when it is not yet available. (8)  

Finally, there is PLOOI. In april 2021, Platform Open Government Information was launched. It is a portal where all public government documents can be searched. Here, everybody will be able to find the documents that will be made public under the new Open Government Act (Woo), when it enters into force. This portal (still a pilot for now), will make data more findable and therefore more reusable for citizens, companies and others that want to use government information. (9)

With regards to open data in particular, the Digitalisation Strategy discusses the importance of data reuse, and states that for good reuse, data should be open and linkable. That is why more and more government domains are adopting the FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Re-usable) principle and making data open by default. So companies and citizens can reuse and share the data as much as possible, in innovative ways. (10) The initiatives and platforms for sharing and using data that are discussed in this strategy, aim at open data just as well as non-open data. Second, an effort aimed specifically at open data, is the Stuiveling Open Data Awards: a yearly award for the initiative (business, science, journalism or whatever) that makes the best use of open government data. (11) 
Third, Data.government.nl of course, was developed especially to make sharing and re-use of open data possible. Furthermore, the projects and action points within the Action Plan Open Government are also all focussed on open data: both making it available and facilitating valuable reuse. 

The government supports the reuse of data from different sources. The initiatives discussed in the Digitalisation Strategy (see third Governance-question),  focus not only on sharing data between governments and private sectors, but also between different private sectors. For example, an ecosystem has been set up so parties from the car and transport industry can share and use anonymised sensordata from hundreds of thousands of vehicles, which can be used by governments and road authorities to improve road safety. (12) Furthermore, there is incidental evidence of efforts to support crowdsourced data reuse, but it is not a structural effort that is reflected in the framework. For example, the RIVM (National Institute for Public Health and Environment) uses 'citizens science' to conduct research into environment and health subjects. They have multiple projects, like 'farmers and neighbors', in which farmers and local residents of the municipality Venray measure air quality from their property for a year. The RIVM will use this data to develop solutions for a cattle farming that is durable and healthy with regards to pollution. (13) And the Data Sharing Coalition  is developing applications and use cases to use data from the 'smart meters' that measure energy consumption in people's homes, to offer consumers better support, like sustainability advice. (14) There is no evidence of the government promoting or supporting the use of data that originates from NGO's. 

Government efforts supporting data reuse, cover a  wide range of topics. The Digitalisation Strategy for example discusses energy and sustainability, transport, agriculture and environment, transport and mobility, health care and science. (15) The NL DIGITAL: Data Agenda Government is limited to reuse of data by governments, but covers topics like climate change, energy transition, safety and subversive crime, and all types of public service towards citizens. (16) On Data.government.nl, datasets are organised in seventeen different categories: governance, culture and recreation, economy, finances, housing, international, farming, migration and integration, nature and environment, education and science, public order and safety, law, space and infrastructure,  social security, traffic, work, health and health care. They host and support the following data communities: Data social security, Energy data, Mobility data, Education data, and Data from the migration chain. (17) The Action Plan Open Government is divided into seven thematic areas (with subtopics): Open Democracy, Open Information, Open Communication, Open Organisation, Open Procurement, Open Technology, Open Justice. (18) 

The government strategy for data reuse aims at multiple user groups. For instance civil society organisations, who are included in the Action Plan Open Government as partners. (19) And Datagovernment.nl is also meant for civil society, as can be deduced from some of the impact stories that are showcased on the platform. (20) Furthermore, the government sometimes finances data reuse initiatives by civil society organisaties. For example, the Ministry of Interior Affairs financed the platform 'Where is my polling station': a website with an interactive map that Open State Foundation built by collecting and processing polling station data from every municipality in the country. (21) 
However, when it comes to civil society there is still a lot of potential reuse that does not receive attention or funding from the government. 

Second, there are no specific support efforts focused on the media. But the Action Plan Open Government mentions journalists as a user group. For instance, it states that government procurement data should be open so journalists (amongst others) can research unfair practices and corruption. (22) Media and journalists also use data from the portal Data.government.nl. A lot of the submitted data requests that can be found on the platform come from journalists. And journalists also submit a lot of FOI-requests, but a lot of the Wob (Public Access to Government Information Act) requests take months, more often than not exceeding the allowed term. (23) This is where government efforts should be focussed. 

Third, the Action Plan Open Government mentions reuse by 'academics' multiple times. (24) However, Open Science and Open Access are not common practice in the Netherlands yet, and there is no widespread common policy stimulating data sharing and reuse in the science domain. Although, the Dutch Organisation for Scientific Research (NWO), an independent government organisation, does promote and stimulate open science and data sharing in the domain. (25) And from interviews with journalists, that were held for example as part of the earlier mentioned research into users of open procurement data, we know that scientists can always submit datarequest with a government agency, which often result in the data being granted on the basis of a confidentiality agreement, when it is used for scientific purposes only. Furthermore, in 2020, the European Open Science Cloud (EOSC) was founded, which will become an open data portal and ecosystem  for data sharing and reuse in the science domain. (26) And agreements were made at a GOFAIR/CODATA symposium, about data sharing and using for science, between regional clouds in Europe, Africa, the US, China and Australia. (27) 

The Digitalisation Strategy (file attached), focuses largely on data re-use by private sectors, like agriculture, energy, transport and other businesses.  For instance, iSHARE is a collaboration between the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Ministry of Infrastructure and the Environment, which helps the transport and logistics sector improve efficiency and reduce costs and CO2-missions through sharing and using data, by connecting stakeholders in a trust framework. (28) The Open Government Action Plan also repeatedly recognizes the importance of open data for reuse by companies, and naturally, the data portal Data.overheid.nl is also aimed at private sectors. The impact stories, applications and case studies they showcase are mostly from private sectors. (29)

As shown above the government supports the reuse of data in different ways. For example, every once in a while the government organizes hackathons around a certain challenge. For example, in 2020, the Ministry of Economic Affairs organised a data-hackathon for the transport and logistics sector, to improve the matching of existing supply of digitisation to the needs of small businesses. (30) And the Accountability Hack has been organised multiple times, with the goal of solving certain government policy issues by developing a tool with the use of open data. (31) Plus, in July 2020, the University of Utrecht organized a hackthon for Data-trainees from the State I-Traineeship. The theme was COVID-19 and its effects on Dutch society. (32) Depending on the department or ministry, the government also organizes communication and community building efforts. The ministry of Defense for instance, does not, but the Ministry of Health, Welfare and Sport, lately has really been pushed to organise public sessions to update interested parties on corona related data. And there are the mentioned Open Data Communities on Data.government.nl. There is also a community of programmers, CODE for NL, that organises training, appathons and meetups. CODE  for NL is not a government initiative, but the community sometimes contributes to government projects. For example, they contributed to an app that could help the Public Health Service (GGD) track contacts of people infected with the coronavirus, more efficiently. This was possible because the government opened up this ICT project to the public, so experts from different disciplines could contribute. (33)  Furthermore, there are government initiatives and organizations focussed on communication about using data. For example: Statistics Netherlands (CBS), organised an event about data use (for the 7th time), informing data users about different techniques and exchanging experiences, when they launched their data portal. (34) And Learning and Expertise Point Open Government organises events and meetups to bring stakeholders together. (35)

indicators.justification:
There are different initiatives, organisations and platforms supporting open data. Most of those discussed under the question above also encourage the availability and  open data. For example, NL DIGITAL Agenda Government, the main strategy when it comes to digitalisation and promoting data-driven work within governments. But the most important initiatives when it comes to making open data available and usable, are Forum Standardisation, a government advisory commission prescribing open standards for data publication (1), and the national open data portal, Data.government.nl. This is a platform where governments can publish and automatically update datasets or data catalogues, which also showcases examples of open data activities and impact. And through the support channel of the Data.government.nl portal, a handbook and other guidance can be found, helping government organisations with the publication of open data. There is also a forum and ways to contact them. (2)  Forum Standardisation offers guidance through prescribing technical publication standards for different types of data, and also helps governments take the necessary steps. (3) Learning and Expertise Point Open Government who offers roadmaps and toolkits for publishing open data and organizes knowledge and expertise sharing through meetups and events (4). 

The Ministry of Interior affairs is responsible for digitalisation and data related initiatives. When it comes to publishing open data, the portal and database Data.government.nl is the most important. The portal is maintained by the Knowledge and Exploitation Centre for Official Government Publications (KOOP) on behalf of the Ministry (5). And the Ministry assigns the members of Forum Standardisation. This team is made up of experts from government organisations, businesses and science (6). Furthermore, the Ministry is behind the Learning and Expertise point Open Government, consisting of two team members (7). The Ministry also created the entity Digital Government, which is for instance responsible for Nl DIGITAL Data Agenda Government (8), and the Digital Government Board and CIO State Board (9).

Open data activities fall under 'Government services and information society' in the state budget. For example, NL DIGITAL Data Agenda Government, falls under 'information policy', for which almost two million (1.961.000)  euros was allocated in 2021. (10)

indicators.justification:
The extent to which city, regional and local governments have the capability to effectively manage data, really depends. In general, The Association of Netherlands Municipalities (VNG) concluded in 2020: "In the field of open data policy, in municipalities most attention is paid to administrative active disclosure. The facilitating aspect of open data, such as data at the request of citizens, chain partners or stakeholders and the possibility of realising facilities together, generally receive less attention. (1) 

In the field of open data policy, most attention in municipalities is paid to administrative
on administrative active disclosure. The facilitating aspect of open
data, such as data at the request of citizens, chain partners or stakeholders
and the possibility of realising facilities together, generally receive less attention.



A lot of provinces and a lot of bigger municipalities have open data initiatives. However, there are also lot's of (smaller) municipalities that do not have the budget or capacity to prioritise open data initiatives. VNG concluded, on the basis of another inventarisation, that there appear to be major differences between how municipalities deal with data and data platforms. (VNG, 'Managing data from the city' (in Dutch), file attached). It also really depends on the theme. For example some municipalities and waterboards offer lots of environmental and climate adaptation data, others offer more financial data.

Many municipalities and provinces have some sort of data portal. For example: Utrecht (https://geo-point.provincie-utrecht.nl/, province and  https://utrecht.dataplatform.nl/#/home, municipality), Amsterdam municipality (https://data.amsterdam.nl/), Apeldoorn municipality ( https://www.apeldoorn.nl/ter/dataportaal), Province Zealand (https://dataportaal.zeeland.nl/dataportaal/srv/dut/catalog.search#/home),  Province North Brabant  (https://data-portaal-noord-brabant.hub.arcgis.com/pages/open-data), municipality Nijmegen: https://opendata.nijmegen.nl/, municipality Heemstede (https://gemeente-heemstede.opendata.arcgis.com/), province South Holland (https://opendata.zuid-holland.nl/geonetwork/srv/dut/catalog.search#/home), municipality Haarlem  (https://www.haarlem.nl/opendata/), municipality Arnhem (https://opendata.arnhem.nl/), municipality The Hague (https://denhaag.dataplatform.nl/#/home), and water board Rijn en IJssel: https://opendata-wrij.opendata.arcgis.com/. However, according to the Association of Municipalities Netherlands (VNG), there are big differences between these platforms. Some offer only open data, some don't, some data has user restrictions, some has not. Also, they offer data on different subjects. Some of them only offer GEO-data for example. The VNG has classified different types of platforms according to a scale (from open to closed, private to public, internal to external): closed data > virtual data warehouse > internal government data platform > municipal data platform > municipal data ecosystem. (2) 

There are also concrete data projects. According to VNG, all municipalities now participate to some extent in data cooperation projects.  For example, the municipality of Eersel, has been working since 2016 on data-driven solutions for monitoring air quality, traffic and parking pressure, landscaping and water management. Some of the goals are saving energy and reducing CO2 emissions. And Helmond is carrying out 'smart city' initiatives, like the 'digital neighbourhood', for which data and open standards are used to secure interoperability of all services and systems. Data is offered as open data through a platform, in line with the municipalities open data principles. The municipality of Zwolle uses data to solve problems relating to transport, health and safety. In the Stadhagen neighbourhood, it worked with partners such as the RIVM (National Institute for Public Health and Environment) and KNMI (Royal Dutch Meteorological Institute) on the Senshagen project, in which residents measured the effect of fireworks on air quality by fitting sensors to their homes. The data from this project is available as open data. Furthermore, the Province of Gelderland has developed the 'Statistical Pocketbook', the Province of Overijssel made a Statistics Database and the
Province of Utrecht a Ubase for tourism and culture. And examples of successful data cooperation at the national level are: Open Council Information and Open Polling Stations. (3)

Furthermore, a lot of provinces and larger municipalities have data policies in the form of data strategies (of which open data is often a part), but not all smaller municipalities have the capacity or budget to develop such a policy, plus in a lot of localities there is just not much attention or priority on open data or data driven working yet. Examples of strategies: the North Holland datavision 2020-2025 (4), North Brabant datavision 2020-2025 (5), The Hague Data strategy 2020-2022 (6), and the Amsterdam data strategy 2021-2022 (7). Data strategies cover government information on all kinds of themes, that is shared with citizens and private sectors, as well as crowd sourced data that is used in smart city initiatives for example, and private sector data that governments are able to publish in their data portals through procurement. (8)

Activities and facilities to share data (internally and externally) in municipalities, cities and provinces, are part of the larger local frameworks of data strategies and data portals. Because these were developed to solve certain societal issues and improve certain services, for which data sharing is vital. Municipalities or provinces achieve a 'data ecosystem', when there is a framework that ensures the circulation and sharing of data. For example, The municipality of Zwolle has an active policy on data use in the city to tackle social challenges, consisting of sharing data and using technology to solve problems related to transport, health and safety. (9) And the North Holland data strategy covers data sharing ('delen') and the necessary infrastructure as part of many action points. However, some local data policies do not mention sharing specifically. And there is no evidence of any local legal frameworks when it comes to data sharing. 

Also, regarding policies for data publishing, there are big differences between provinces and municipalities. A lot of data portals work on a voluntary basis: some information is published , some is not, some data is open, some is not. A few data strategies and data portals really focus on consistent publication of more and more data, using open standards. However, even data portals from big municipalities often still contain very little data sets (f.i. Utrecht: 709). This shows there are no concrete rules or guidelines in place for consistent publication and management. 

In terms of training civil servants on data literacy and skills, there is some evidence of local frameworks and initiatives.  For example, the municipality of Rotterdam has an internal program for stimulating data-driven working, which amongst other things focusses on civil servants data skills. (10) And the University of Utrecht created the Data School, a 'data work place', which connects regional and local governments to academic research about data. (11) However, many smaller municipalities don't prioritize data literacy or skills. Therefore, VNG has created the 'Development model for data-driven working for municipalities'. Municipalities can use it to check their 'data maturity'. (12) However, there is no guarantee that this model will actually be used by municipalities.  

With respect to support for data reuse, A lot of the data portals (see earlier questions for examples) offer some information for users, and for instance the municipality of Amsterdam, offers data services: API's that can be used to better link and search data (13), but there do not seem to be many local initiatives in this sphere.

Lastly, municipalities enable the impact of national facilities and systems by providing data to central government, provinces and/or implementing organisations, for instance all the data for the ten basic registries of the country.

indicators.justification:
There is no standard, centralized training that civil servants and government organisations go through, but there are lots of initiatives and platforms that are at their disposal if they wish to use them to find information, or develop knowledge and skills. For the most part, government initiatives to train civil servants on data matters are laid down in NL DIGITAL: Data Agenda Government. The objective of this agenda is to promote the sharing, combining and analysis of data through cooperation between governments. The element consists of five elements, the last two of which are relevant here: 4. Collecting and sharing knowledge on working data-driven,  and 5. Investing in people, organisations and culture change'. (1) As part of number 4, the Learning and Expertise Center Data-driven working (LED) was set up. Here, best practices, methods and techniques and knowledge about data-driven working are collected and shared. (2) For example, they created the Data Governance Self-assessment tool, consisting of 43 questions on 8 themes, determining the position and ambition of a government organisation when it comes to data governance. Also, in 2020 LED launched the 'Toolkit Data-driven Working', with methods, techniques, prerequisites, best practices, case studies, interviews, tips from experts, information on ethical and legal aspects, et cetera. (3) Another example included in the Data Agenda Government, is the Den Bosch Data Week that the Ministry of Interior Affairs supports. This week is about showing government organisations and other target audiences what the social value of data can be. (4) Also, different knowledge conferences are organised by different government organisations. (5) 

Element 5 of the Data Agenda focuses on recruiting new talent, education, training and development of civil servants, setting up an infrastructure of datalabs and data science workspaces, promoting better data management, and changing the way of working within government organisations. For instance, government organisations are being encouraged to hire a Chief Data Officer and develop a data strategy, like more and more public bodies are doing. The Directorate CIO State is developing a blueprint for the role of Chief Data Officers. (6) Furthermore in 2019 the National Academy for Digitalisation and Computerisation in Government (RADIO) has launched an e-learning module on the impact and opportunities of digitisation for policy staff. They also organise different seminars, webinars, podcasts, e-learnings, access to Digi-Coaches, LinkedIn-groups, and courses to teach civil servants about data, cyber security, AI, digital skills, et cetera. (7) Also, in 2019 the government, together with the Technical University of Delft, started the Digicampus, where scientists, government bodies, businesses and citizens work together on digital government innovations to improve public service, including through use of data. (8) Furthermore, the Ministry of Interior Affairs and the Association of the Netherlands Municipalities, are developing international framework guidelines for responsible data use, through the working group 'Data Driven Public Sector' of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), which is chaired by the Netherlands. (9) For more examples, see the NL DIGITAL: Data Agenda Government (file attached). 

Additionally, there's the Learning and Expertise Point Open Government, which is focussed on sharing knowledge and experiences when it comes to open data. They offer tools and instruments and bring civil servants in contact with experts. For example, through the project 'Breakthrough with Open Data', open data relays were organised, where NGOs, governments and other stakeholders came together to solve social issues with data. Furthermore, they offer an Open Data Toolkit, with i.e. a roadmap and practical tips to get started with open data. (10) 

Lastly, the national data platform, Data.government.nl, offers open data knowledge and technical support. For example through the Open Data Guide, that civil servants can use to achieve open data within their organisation. (11)
