indicators.justification:
The Trade Register Act (Handelsregisterwet, Hrw 2007) obliges the Chamber of Commerce (Kamer van Koophandel, KvK) to keep and publish a register with company information. (1) On December 27th, 2020, the Act implementing registration of ultimate beneficial owners of legal entities (Implementatiewet registratie uiteindelijke belanghebbenden) came into force. This act amends the 2007 Trade Register Act (Handelsregisterwet), the Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Act (Wwft) and a number of other laws relating to the obligation to have, maintain and centrally register information about ultimate beneficial owners ('ultimate beneficial owners', abbreviated UBOs) of companies and other legal entities incorporated in the Netherlands. (2) 

This Implementation Act has set up an UBO-register, by adding paragraph d to article 2 of the Hrw 2007, which entered into force in January 2020. (3) This paragraph states there should be a register with 'ultimate beneficiaries to prevent the use of the financial system for money laundering and terrorist financing'. For the definition of an UBO, article 1 paragraph 1 of the Hrw 2007 refers to article 10a paragraph 1 of the Wwft. (4) An UBO is the owner of a company (someone who owns more that 25% of shares or voting rights), or someone who is effectively in control of a company. (5) The obligation to publish the data, lies with the KvK, and is set out in Chapter 4 ('The provision and use of data') of the Hrw 2007, mostly in articles 21 and 22. Limitations to this obligation may be set by General Administrative Order (AMvB), to protect the privacy of persons who are registered in the register (article 23 of the Hrw 2007). Type of entities that are not required to register themselves through the UBO register are sole proprietorships, listed BV's and NV's,100% subsidiaries of listed companies, owners associations, associations with limited legal capacity that do not run a business, legal entities in formation legal entities under public law, other legal entities under private law, including historical legal entities (such as guilds and almshouses). (6)

There is no legal requirement for published company data, including UBO-data, to contain 'open data', in the sense that it's free of charge, free of rights, and machine readable for instance. However, the fourth EU Directive for the prevention of money laundering and terrorism financing, and the Hrw 2007, do require the data to be available to the general public (albeit through pay or registration barriers). (7) So the KvK publishes it online, and provides an API to search through it, but to access the data users need to register and pay a fee of 2,50 per extract. (9) The quality of the data is secured through a 'terugmeldplicht' (feedback obligation) laid down in the Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Prevention Act (Wwft), Article 10b, paragraph 2. Wwft institutions and competent authorities are obliged to report back if UBO data is incorrect. You can report the following: missing UBOs in the UBO register; persons who are incorrectly listed in the UBO register; or an incorrect interest or extent of the interest of a UBO. (9) Additionally, Chapter 7 of the Hrw 2007 is dedicated to quality control. Article 41 states that on the basis of Article 393 of Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code, the information in de company register is verified by an accountant once every three years.  (10) Article 40 of the Hrw 2007 requires that the data is accurate, complete and regularly updated. (11)

indicators.justification:
Government websites still contain large amounts of files (often pdf's) that are not open and accessible. However, from September 23rd 2020, the entire government is legally required to offer all information and services in a digitally accessible way, meaning people with a functional impairment can use them as easily as people without a disability. (1) According to Article 3 of the Temporary Decree on Digital Accessibility for Government, public authorities must make their websites and mobile applications accessible by applying the standard EN 301 549, except if and in so far as this would impose 'a disproportionate burden'. Whether such a burden exists, depends on financial resources of the government organisation and the estimated costs and benefits to the public authority concerned in relation to the estimated benefits to persons with disabilities. The requirement entails that all government websites, including websites that were commissioned by the government, and all the information on these platforms, need to have an 'accessibility statements'. (2)

With the Decree of Digital Accessibility for Government, the Web Accessibility Directive (Directive (EU) 2016/21/02) has been implemented. This directive requires "an accessibility statement for each website and mobile app; a feedback mechanism so users can flag accessibility problems or request information published in a non-accessible content; regular monitoring of public sector websites and apps by Member States, and reporting on the results." (3) The monitoring is performed within government-bodies, through inter-governmental supervision by provinces and ministries. They share their findings with Logius (from the Ministry of Interior Affairs), who reports yearly to the House of Representatives and every three years to the European Commission. Logius also helps public bodies achieve accessibility, for instance with the handbook they published. This handbook explains, amongst other things, what should be included in the accessibility statement. The Ministry of Interior Affairs has developed a model for this statement, 'Digitoegankelijk', based on the model that the European Commission established: the EN 301 549 norm, which uses the technical standard WCAG 2.1. WCAG 2.1 was developed by the W3C and is the global standard for web accessibility. The statement should (amongst other things) include whether research has been conducted yet (which has to be done following the WCAG-EM method or an equivalent documented evaluation method for the WCAG 2.1-standard), and if so whether this research shows complete compliance. (4) 

Another ground for offering information in an inclusive and accessible manner, is the 'Equal treatment on the grounds of disability or chronic illness act', which has been in force since 2003. This act determines that no one can be excluded because of their disability, neither offline nor digitally. It applies to education, labor and transport, as well as products and services (data). (5) Furthermore, the accessibility requirement will be laid down in the Digital Governance Act, which (due to pending adjustments) will not be in force for at least another year. (6)

(2) Tijdelijk besluit digitale toegankelijkheid overheid, 2018, Chapter 2: Toegankelijkheid, Article 3 and 4, https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0040936/2018-07-01. 
(3) European Commission, 'Web Accessibility', https://digital-strategy.ec.europa.eu/en/policies/web-accessibility, and Directive (EU) 2016/2102 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 26 October 2016 on the accessibility of the websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies, https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/dir/2016/2102/oj. 
(4) Logius (Ministry of Intererior Affairs and Kingdom Relations), 'Over de verklaring', https://www.digitoegankelijk.nl/toegankelijkheidsverklaring/over-de-verklaring, and Logius (Ministry of Intererior Affairs and Kingdom Relations), 'Digitale toegankelijkheid in jouw organisatie: wie doet wat?', p. 9 (file attached), and Forum Standaardisatie, 'Digitoegankelijk (EN 301 549 met WCAG 2.1)', https://www.forumstandaardisatie.nl/open-standaarden/digitoegankelijk-en-301-549-met-wcag-21. 
(5) Wet gelijke behandeling op grond van handicap of chronische ziekte, 2003, https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0014915/2017-01-01, and Logius (Ministry of Intererior Affairs and Kingdom Relations), 'Digitale toegankelijkheid in jouw organisatie: wie doet wat?', p. 7 (file attached). 
(6)  Logius (Ministry of Intererior Affairs and Kingdom Relations), 'Digitale toegankelijkheid in jouw organisatie: wie doet wat?', p. 7 (file attached).

responses.subquestion_text: Where does this requirement exist?
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
There is no comprehensive legal framework in place (yet). Through the Digital Government Act, the use of open standards will become mandatory, but due to a pending legislative amendment, the law will not be implemented until at least juli 2022. (1) Currently the Government Information Reusability Act ('Wet herbruikbaarheid overheidsinformatie') dictates that all public information should, when requested be provided 'the way it is available at the government agency' (so in raw form), and 'as much as possible' in an open and machine-readable format, according to formal standards. So this is just a 'best effort'-rule, plus this act only applies to information that is requested, so the rule does not apply to active publishing of information. (2) However, there are some laws and quality frameworks (with force of law) that cover the ten national basic registers ('basisregistraties'), like the Trade Register and the Personal Records Database. These differ per register and will be discussed further below. 

In addition, data management, standards and quality are addressed in the Dutch Digitalisation Strategy. (3) And it is part of the third element of the NL DIGITAL: Data Agenda Government, which is called 'Improving the quality of government data and using it more efficiently'. The strategy and the agenda describe different programs and initiatives aimed at publishing and managing data in a better way. For example, promoting the adoption of the FAIR principles (Findable,Accessible, Interoperable, Re-usable) within different government domains. As a result, data from different organizations and standards can be better combined. (4) Also, the Ministry of Interior Affairs has set up an advisory committee consisting of experts from various government organisations, the economic sector and science world, called Forum Standardisation. This committee tests and prescribes open standards for publishing data to government organisations. Through two lists (which have no force of law), called 'recommended' standards and 'apply-or-justify'-standards, they prescribe different standards for different types of data (f.i.: CSV for numeric table files). (5) 

Furthermore, Data.government.nl (data.overheid.nl) is a platform and API  where all governments can and are encouraged to publish open datasets (so far there are 16.013 available sets). In accordance with the DCAT-model, different file formats are allowed, like JSON, RDF, HTML, etc. (6) Lastly, an important initiative is the program plan for the improvement of the system of basic registers. Data from these registers is being used more than 40 million times a day, for instance by governments when they grant licenses or subsidies, but also by citizens and companies when navigating to an address or looking up house prices. In the system, data from the different registers is linked to each other. The program addresses access to and correction of data,  re-use of data and quality management. (7)  

There is no legal framework setting obligations when it comes to publishing metadata. However, when government organisations want to publish their data catalogues on Data.government.nl, the data has to conform to the DCAT-AP-DONL standard for metadata, which makes it possible to link datasets.  DCAT-AP-DONL is a  version of W3C's international standards, developed by Data.government.nl. (8) To prevent users from having to visit all individual catalogues, metadata is collected from various regional, national and thematic catalogues. To standardise the exchange of metadata between catalogues, the DCAT standard was developed. The interoperability between catalogues makes single entry and repeated use possible. This standard has not yet been labeled by Forum Standardisation as 'recommended' or 'apply-or-justify' (its status is still pending), but it soon will be. (9)  On Data.overheid.nl it is also mandatory to add a unique identifier for each dataset as metadata. (10) Forum Standardisation's lists do contain other metadata standards, for other types of data as well. For example, according to the Forum, OWMS should be used to describe 'information objects' that the government publishes on the Internet, such as articles, parliamentary papers, announcements and forms. (11) 


There is no general legal framework setting rules for quality control of government data. And there are no quality norms that apply to all basic registries. However, the ten national basic registers all have certain norms that should be met, some of which  are laid down in the law by which they were created or additional quality frameworks. For instance, the Basic Register Income (BRI), which contains the salaries of 14 million citizens, has to conform to a set of quality rules. An example of a norm is that they should be 99% complete and accurate. The quality norms for the other registers, and research determining to which extent they are met, can be found in the government report 'Quality information system of basic registrations' and in the answers to other indicators (f.i. the Trade Register is dealt with under company information). (12) 

Also, quality is secured to feedback procedures. Registries and databases from individual government organisations can have different rules or procedures for feedback, they are not subjected to any central legal obligation, (13) but this is different for the national basic registers. Firstly, in 2020 a contact point was set up where errors in the basic registers can be reported. (14) And these registers are all subject to a feedback obligation ('terugmeldplicht'), meaning the users of the data (mostly other government bodies) are legally obligated to report discrepancies. In 2018 for example, 110.000 reports were filed. (15) For example, the feedback obligation regarding UBO-data (from the Trade Register) is  laid down in the Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Prevention Act (Wwft), Article 10b, paragraph 2. Wwft institutions and competent authorities are obliged to report back if UBO data is incorrect.  (16) And Article 7n of the Cadastre Act states that 'An administrative body shall report to the Service, stating reasons, its reasonable doubt about the accuracy of a data entry in the land register which has been designated as authentic by virtue of this Act.' (17) Each basic register has a different legal base with a feedback obligation.

(14) Rijksdienst voor Identiteitsgegevens, 'Meldpunt Fouten in Overheidsregistraties van start', January 4th 2021, https://www.rvig.nl/meldpunt-fouten-in-overheidsregistraties/nieuws/2021/01/04/meldpunt-fouten-in-overheidsregistraties-van-start-kopie.
(15) Digitale overheid, 'Stelsel van basisregistraties. Kwaliteit en terugmelden: beoogde en gerealiseerde kwaliteit', https://www.digitaleoverheid.nl/overzicht-van-alle-onderwerpen/basisregistraties-en-stelselafspraken/stelsel-van-basisregistraties/kwaliteit-en-terugmelden/. 
(16) Wet ter voorkoming van witwassen en financiering van terrorisme, 2008, Chapter 2: 'Bepalingen betreffende cliëntenonderzoek', section 2.4a: 'Informatie over uiteindelijke belanghebbenden', article 10b, paragraph 2, https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0024282/2021-07-01.
(17) Kadasterwet, 1989, Chapter 1a: 'Bepalingen omtrent authentieke gegevens en de inhoud en inrichting van registraties', Title 3: 'Terugmelding', Article 7n, https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0004541/2021-07-01#Hoofdstuk1a.

responses.response_text: The data management approaches assessed generally apply across the whole public sector.
responses.subquestion_text: How broadly is good data management practice established?

indicators.justification:
There are rights that restrict the sharing, reproduction, and (unlawful) use of certain data, like copyright (1), database rights (2) and the protection of trade secrets (3). There is no legal framework for data sharing. Governments and companies are free to come up with their own conditions for data sharing (apart from the data that must be available as open data or on the basis of FOI requests, but these types were discussed in the previous questions). However, there exist partnerships and data sharing initiatives and platforms for data sharing by governments, and for cross-sector data sharing between companies, in various sectors, such as healthcare and transport . These come mainly from the government and a lot of them are mentioned in the Dutch Digitalisation Strategy 2021. An important part of the framework is the program and interdepartmental steering committee Control over Data ('Regie op gegevens'). The committee formed a legal working group that developed proposals for statutory regulation of the sharing of data from government registries with citizens, companies, third parties and private service providers. These proposals will eventually be implemented in the Digital Government Act, which will lay the legal foundation for a basic infrastructure for data sharing and the mandatory use of open standards, but which is not yet in force. (4)

When it comes to data sharing between companies, the government's approach consists of supporting promising initiatives, investigating whether and where regulation is needed, and promoting the development of insights, tools and exchanges of knowledge that could contribute to effective data sharing. (5) For instance, the government has recently  published a report in which the role of data in the tech sector is investigated, in order to explore the possibilities and risks of mandatory data sharing. (6) As part of the Digitalisation Strategy, Ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate Policy published the 'Dutch vision on data sharing between businesses', in which it discusses three principles that are central to the government's approach: 'voluntary data sharing is preferable', 'data sharing will be made compulsory, if necessary', and 'people and businesses retain control of their data'. The document also discusses how the government is planning on implementing this vision.(7) 

In order to stimulate voluntary cross-sectoral data sharing and to come to agreements on this, a group of data sharing initiatives, industries, companies and knowledge institutions were brought together in an open collaboration for cross-sectoral data sharing, the Data Sharing Coalition (DSC), at the Cabinet's initiative in 2019. The government supports this coalition, so that pilot projects to share data between different sectors can be carried out. The goal is to create better interoperability between  existing - often sector-specific - data-sharing initiatives, which requires agreements on f.i. technical standards, data semantics, legal agreements and reliable, reusable digital identities. (8) As of April 2021, the coalition consists of 38 participating organisations and companies. The initiative  is not limited to Dutch borders and is open to participants from all countries. (9) 

In 2018 the Ministry of Economic Affairs conducted research into many data sharing platforms and initiatives, exploring the possibilities for a system of agreements on data sharing, to fill the gaps in the existing infrastructure of initiatives. (10) Among these initiatives are 'data trusts'. These make it easier for individual parties, including consumers and businesses, to agree on conditions for data access and data sharing that adequately safeguard their interests, which is especially needed when companies with strong negotiating power are involved. Examples of these trusts in different sectors  include IRMA, Qiy, Medmij, iSHARE, JOINDATA and OCKTO. All of them ensure a trusted way of sharing data by properly securing the various interests, thereby making it possible to use the data for economic and social purposes. (11) For instance, iSHARE is a collaboration between the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Ministry of Infrastructure and the Environment, that helps the transport and logistics sector improve efficiency and reduce costs and CO2-missions, by connecting stakeholders in a trust framework. All participants can decide what they want to share and with whom, following generic agreements and standards that were developed for the sector. (12) With regard to the same sector, the Digital Transport Strategy was developed, to get to 'digital by default'.  From 2025, the 'Basic Data Infrastructure' will enable decentralised data sharing between different companies and governments for all forms of transport. (13) Furthermore, from 2018 to 2020  the Ministry of Infrastructure had conducted research into 'smart mobility'. To allow increasingly automated and digitalised vehicles to operate smoothly and safely, the National Mobility Data Access Point is being launched, to centralize and open up data on road traffic and multimodal travel information. (14)

Examples from the tech and transport sector have been mentioned, but their are also frameworks for other sectors, like health care, agriculture, and energy. For instance, because not all hospitals have means to exchange data (radiological images, laboratory results, etc.) between hospitals, which is important when patients are being dispersed due to the pandemic, the COVID-19 Portal from Philips has been recommended to hospitals as a temporary solution. (15). As for agriculture: farmers are producing more and more data and their machines are increasingly digitally connected. This creates opportunities to produce more efficiently, for example through (self-learning) algorithms and the use of robots,  in the field, in logistics and in product processing. However, farmers find that they have little control over the use of and access to the data they generate. This way data sharing  can affect privacy, autonomy, economic position and market power. To give farmers more control and security, the Top Sector programme Precision Farming 4.0 is working on an infrastructure for sharing agrodata, the Agricultural Data Facility. (16) As far as the energy sector is concerned, the Data Sharing Coalition is currently developing a use case where consumers can use their energy data to understand the potential for energy-saving measures (like thermal pumps or solar panels) in their specific household. Also, a proposal for the new Energy Act (implementing the EU Electricity Directive) is being prepared. This legislation should improve the cooperation in the chain of measuring data, the availability of high quality and high frequency data and the access to and sharing of data. (17) However, in the consultation that was held, and advisory body states that is is impossible to determine the effectiveness of the law, because the obligations have not been sufficiently elaborated. (18) 

The (examples of) frameworks above focus on data sharing between companies and between government and companies. For data-sharing within the government, there is no central, legal framework either. Governmental organisations may draw up their own policy documents, terms of use and licences with regard to data. For instance, the Chamber of Commerce limits the use of company information, the Land Registry manages land data that is partly public and partly closed due to privacy issues, and KNMI shares almost all weather information. However, data sharing within the government is covered by the Dutch Digitalisation Strategy. An important part of the framework is the NL DIGITAL: Data Agenda Government, which focuses on solving social problems with data, stimulating data-driven work by government organisations, sharing data and improving data-quality. (19)  To further stimulate data-driven work on societal issues, the government has developed infrastructures to bring together knowledge, skills, technical infrastructure and data in data labs. Like the CBS (statistics) data ecosystem, the police information organisation, different departmental data labs and the Regional and National Information and Expertise Centres. (20) Also, the government conducts FAIR data pilots. For example, the Drought & Flooding pilot project aims to make water quantity data from water boards and the national water authority FAIR at the source, to obtain overview and better manage water in periods of drought or extreme rainfall. The FAIR Guiding Principles for scientific data management stand for: Findability, Accesibility, Interoperability, and Reuse of digital assets. (21) Furthermore, for government organizations there's Pleio: an open source collaboration platform for knowledge sharing between  government organizations. (22) Lastly, the Association of Netherlands Municipalities has formulated the Principles for the Digital Society, in order to set an example for the business community and show them the frameworks that local governments set with regard to data collection and use. These principles (f.i. 'data is open by default' and 'initiatives should serve the common good as much as possible') are translated at the national level into government-wide principles. (23) 

Finally, data sharing in the Netherlands is affected by the European framework. However, for a large part this framework is still being developed and not yet in force. The European Strategy for Data aims at creating a single market for data. Amongst other things, it intends to 'adopt legislative measures on data governance, access and reuse. For example, for business-to-government data sharing for the public interest' and '​​make data more widely available by opening up high-value publicly held datasets across the EU and allowing their reuse for free'. (24) And in November 2020, the European Commission published a proposal for the Data Governance Act, which aims to improve the availability of data in the EU by developing a framework for public data sharing and increasing trust in data intermediaries, and by strengthening data sharing mechanisms in the EU, for instance by lowering transaction costs of B2B and C2B data sharing. However, it remains to be seen what form the final law will take. (25) Furthermore, initiatives are being taken at the EU level. For instance, the European Data for Road Safety trial, which was successfully completed and thus scaled up to a permanent exchange. Under Dutch chairmanship, a data ecosystem has been set up with member states and industry parties in which anonymous sensor data from hundreds of thousands of vehicles is shared with governments and road authorities to prevent unsafe situations and to detect and share information with drivers. (26) And for the science domain, the European Open Science Cloud (EOSC) was established. In December 2020, agreements were ratified on data sharing for scientific research between regional clouds in Europe, Africa, the US, China and Australia: the FAIR Digital Object21 agreements. These form the basis for a Web of FAIR Data & Service. (27)

indicators.justification:
The General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/679)(GDPR, AVG in Dutch), which has direct effect in all EU-countries, and the Dutch General Data Protection Regulation Implementation Act (GDPRIA, UAVG in Dutch). The GDPR applies to the processing of all personal data (Article 2). The definitions of data 'controllers' and 'processors' cover all private and public sectors. (1) 

Chapter 6 of the GDPR dictates that each member state should have an independent supervisory authority ensuring and monitoring the application of the regulation, 'in order to protect the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons in relation to processing and to facilitate the free flow of personal data within the Union' (Article 51, 52). Among other things, this authority monitors data protection, advises legislative and administrative government bodies, and handles complaints lodged by data subjects, organizations or others (Article 57(1.f)(2)). The Dutch Data Protection Authority (DPA) is called the Autoriteit Persoonsgegevens. The mentioned fundamental rights are Article 8 European Convention on Human Rights and Article 8 of the EU Charter of Fundamental rights. (2)

Data processors (when they are a public body, or when processing data is their main activity or they do it on a large scale) need to appoint a data protection officer, who registers with and reports to the national authority, and is responsible for GDPR-compliance. This is implemented thorugh the GDPRIA. (3) Furthermore, Article 68 of the GDPR established the European Data Protection Board, which is composed of the heads of the supervisory authority of member states. It is responsible for the consistent application of the DDPR. It's tasks consist of monitoring, advising the EU Commission, and issuing guidelines, recommendations and best practices for data processors, governments and supervisory authorities (Article 70 GDPR). Also it issues opinions when national authorities take certain measures and settles disputes between or within national authorities (Articles 64 & 65). (4)

Article 77 of the GDPR gives data subjects the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority and Article 78 contains the right to an effective judicial remedy against this supervisory authority. Article 79 adds a right to an effective judicial remedy against a data controller or processor. Together these articles ensure an effective right to redress. (5) 

Data controllers have to comply with the core principles and responsibilities set out in article 5 GDPR. I.a. taking steps to ensure personal information is updated and accurate; limiting access to personal data in accordance with its intended use; only transferring data to third-parties if there are assurances they will also respect data protection rights; destroying or anonymising data after it is no longer needed for its original intended use. The Controller is responsible for ensuring third parties comply to the principles as well (Article 5 Paragraph 2, and Article 4, Paragraph 1). Rules related to  transferring of data are set out in Chapter 5. (6) 

Data controllers and processors must implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure a level of security appropriate to existing security  risks (Article 32 GDPR). The GDPR requires a personal data breach to be notified, without undue delay (max. 72 hours) by the controller to its supervisory authority, and for more serious breaches to be notified to the affected data subjects as well (Article 33 & 34). Article 4 defines a data breach as a 'breach of security leading to the accidental or unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to, personal data transmitted, stored or otherwise processed'. (7) 

The framework contains specific rules covering algorithmic decision-making. To 'ensure fair and transparent processing', the controller has to provide a data subject with (access to) information on the existence of automated decision-making, including profiling, and meaningful information about the logic involved, as well as the significance and the envisaged consequences of such processing for the data subject (Article 13(2.f), 14(2.g) and 15(1.h) GDPR). Article 22 GDPR formulates a prohibition on fully automated individual decision-making that is based on profiling, if it has a legal or otherwise significant impact on the data subject. (8) According to the Dutch DPA, this means: 'important decisions should not be made by an algorithm alone, without human intervention'. (9) However, Article 22 provides three exceptions. Automated decision making is allowed when it is: necessary for entering into or performing a contract, authorized by EU or Member State law, or the data subject has given their explicit (opt-in) consent. When decisions are taken on the basis of the first and second option, the data subject also has the right to obtain human intervention, to contest the decision, and to express his or her point of view. The Dutch DPA has used the second option to implement exceptions to the prohibition in Article 40 of the GDPRIA, which states that the GDPR does not apply if the automated individual decision-making, other than based on profiling, is necessary for compliance with a legal obligation to which the controller is subject or for the performance of a task carried out for reasons of public interest. (10) So for instance when awarding study or child allowances. (11)

The GDPR does not contain specific rules on location data, but it does consider this to be personal information, so as long as it is not anonymized is falls under the protection of the regulation. The ePrivacy Directive (Directive (EU) 2002/58/EC), which will soon be replaced by the e-privacy directive, handles data protection in the context of telecommunication, so it protects location data related to users' terminal equipment. (12) Also, the European Data Protection Board that oversees the GDPR implementation, on the 21ste of April 2021, issued guidelines (on the basis of Article 70(1.e) GDPR), for the use of location data and contact tracing tools in the context of the COVID-19 outbreak. It has developed rules on the data, the purpose of use, security, et cetera. However, the guidelines are not binding. (13) 

No other additions or changes to the legal framework have been made. However, in March 2020 the Dutch DPA announced it would be making some adjustments to its approach, in light of Covid-19. They wrote that the DPA is "giving governments and companies room to focus on combating corona during the corona crisis. For example, organizations will be given more time to respond to questions from the AP where necessary, and the DPA will give initiatives to protect public health plenty of room. But the regulator will continue to intervene where privacy is truly at risk." For example, they allow some  health care facillities that do not have a way to make secure video calls to patient, to use consumer apps like FaceTime or Skype. (14)

indicators.justification:
There are no framework or norms dictating that data should be published in Dutch. By default all government organisations do publish information at least in Dutch (this is just the custom) and some of them also offer English data. Everything in the national database Data.government.nl for example, is available in Dutch, and they are working on getting more and more datasets available in English as well. (1) In 2010, a proposal was submitted to embed the Dutch language in the Constitution, but in 2018 it was withdrawn because the proposal did not take into account other official languages used within the Netherlands besides Dutch and Frisian, such as English and Papiamento. In addition, the cabinet found that there is a lack of social need. (2)

indicators.justification:
The Archive Act (Archiefwet) provides rules on how governments should preserve and manage information, in a durable and accessible way. Article 14 of this law dictates that all archival records should be open to the public, free of charge, and that reuse of the information (both copying and altering) should be allowed. Article 15 contains a few justifications that allow (limited) restriction of public access, namely respect for privacy, the interest of the State or its allies, or preventing disproportionate advantage of disadvantage of persons or organizations. (1) When citizens want to access information that is not available in any archive or for instance on government websites, they can submit an information request based on the Public Access to Government Information Act (Wet openbaarheid van bestuur, Wob). A data request must in principle be granted, unless one of the grounds for exception from articles 10 and 11 apply. These include for example protecting company and manufacturing data or someone's right to privacy. (2)

Article 6 of the Wob determines that a request should be handled 'as soon as possible' and no later than four weeks after it is received. In practice however, a large part of request exceeds this term. A report from independent research agency SEO, shows that over the last few years, the duration of processing a request has increased annually. (3) Furthermore requests, decisions and provided data are not regularly or consistently published. The laws contain no rules that enforce centralized publication. (4) Therefore, Open State Foundation, as a civil society organization, has created OpenWob.nl, where all public Wob-related documents are collected and made searchable. (5) Another problem with the Wob is that it does not impose an obligation of active disclosure. Also, there exists no independent oversight body that inspects the compliance of governments with the Wob and where requesters can lodge complaints. That is why in 2016, the House of Representatives (Tweede Kamer) adopted a proposal for a law replacing the Wob: the Open Government Act (Wet openbaarheid van bestuur), which will instate an obligation of proactive disclosure of (some) government information. This proposal was amended in February 2021. The prospect is that the law will establish an 'advisory commission for transparency and information management' and central platform for all disclosed information. (6) The current proposal also has a broader scope than the Wob, which applies in particular to administrative bodies such as ministries, municipalities and provinces. (7) Pursuant to Article 2.2, the provisions of the Woo will also apply to legislative and judicial bodies, like the Senate and House of Representatives, the Council of the Judiciary, parts of the Council of State, the Court of Audit, the National Ombudsman and boards of public bodies. (8) However, the Woo still needs to be adopted by the Senate (Eerste Kamer), so the precise content and scope remains uncertain. 

The Wob and Woo do not mention reusability: this topic is governed by the Government Information Reusability Act (Wet herbruikbaarheid overheidinformatie, Who). The Who implements the EU Public Sector Information Directive and is therefore focused on the reuse of data for developing and improving products and services. (9) According to article 5 of the Who, all public information should, when requested (so not actively), be provided 'the way it is available at the government agency' (so in raw form), and 'as much as possible' in an open and machine-readable format: a 'best effort'-rule. (10) 

None of the abovementioned acts contain a definition of 'open data'. However, the official government open data platform provides guidelines the required characteristics of open data. These guidelines were established on June 22nd 2016, in a letter that the Minister of the Interior and Kingdom Relations sent to the House of Representatives (Tweede Kamer). The eight guidelines state that open data must be: published pro-actively (unless exceptions from the Woo or Who apply), free of charge, exempt from third party rights, accessible without registration, machine readable, provided with metadata in accordance with the DCAT-AP standard, and as complete and unedited as possible. These requirements lack any force of law. (11)

indicators.justification:
The Netherlands is a country characterised by the decentralisation of public government on three levels: national, provinces and municipalities. Ministries are responsible for their own budget chapter and defend their budgets in parliament. Policy implementation is largely mandated or delegated to departmental agencies and autonomous administrative agencies. Regional and local governments are separate and largely autonomous tiers of government. Due to this, different laws, regulations, policies in place in the Netherlands in regard to the regulation of public finance. The 'Comptabiliteitswet 2016' e.g. Accounts Act requires that the national government publishes pre-budget statements, the executive budget, proposal and supporting documents, the enacted budget, a citizen budget, in-year reports in budget success and execution, mid-year reviews, a year-end report and an audit report (1) Each year the Minister of Finance defines the 'Rijksbegrotingsvoorschriften' e.g. annual regulations (2). It  regulates the reporting requirements and the procedural matters of central government budgets, accounts and documents to be provided to the States General. It provides models for the publication of the financial data by each ministry and includes 5 specific models for the publication of certain financial information as open data. The open data does not fall under the official documents for the budget and the annual report and is not checked by the Central Government Audit Service. For internal financial management all ministries use a central and automated software system called RIS-IBOS. In this system data is structured and categorised, inter alia using the European System of National and Regional Accounts (ESA 2010). Through this system data is shared with the Central Bureau for Statistics and the European Commission (3).

Regarding the verification of this information, The Court of Audit investigates whether the central government spends public money wisely, economically and carefully. Their statutory task is to monitor central government income and expenditure and to report on this to parliament once a year on Accountability Day (third Wednesday in May). Based on their opinion, parliament can decide whether to grant discharge to the cabinet. In addition, they report individual investigations to parliament so that MPs can determine whether a minister's policy is effective (1).

There is no a framework that supports the disclosure of level at its most detailed level e.g. transactions, nor real-time publication. For all types of financial data different updates are required e.g. for in-year reports every month, for budgets each year, etc. (4).

(1) https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0039429/2021-02-13
(2) https://rbv.rijksfinancien.nl/sites/default/files/pdf/Rijksbegrotingsvoorschriften%202021.pdf
(3) https://wettenpocket.overheid.nl/portal/0ff0f42b-2a70-45b7-a9c9-3b4253b292e7/document/Handleiding%20dataverkeer%20RIS-IBOS_20171218.pdf
(4) https://wettenpocket.overheid.nl/portal/7ec1a250-bb0b-4d72-929e-d270ddae2817/document/bijlage-3-memorie-van-toelichting-comptabiliteitswet-2016.pdf

indicators.justification:
The Ambtenarenwet 2017 e.g. the Civil Servants Act 2017 prescribes that the ancillary functions and interests of civil servants should be publicly disclosed if disclosure is necessary to protect the integrity of public service (1). The Act does state that data on  information on assets and liabilities should be collected and published. It does not explicitly state that data should be collected regarding in-kind and non-financial support, on in-kind and non-financial support, significant changes in assets and liabilities and income and assets held by a public official's spouse, family members, or other intimates. 
Also, this Act only applies only to civil servants and excludes members of the judicial branch, ministers, members of parliament and Senate. Members of the House of Representatives and the Senate have their own Codes of Conduct (2 & 3). Ministers, MPs and state secretaries do need to declare gifts above €50,-, ancillary activities and foreign travel expenses, but are not required to disclose their financial interests during their time in office (4). And because the Code of Conduct for members of parliament specifically mentions that they are not sanctioned in case of noncompliance, this disclosure mechanism cannot be considered to be effective.

indicators.justification:
The Act 'financiering politieke partijen' requires political parties to be transparent about their party finance, including the publication gifts, subsidies and liabilities. Each year and with each election, the parties must submit their financial documents to the Minister of the Interior and Kingdom Relations (1). Donors need to be made public, financial contributions need to be explained, information regarding assets and liabilities needs to be disclosed, just as for income, spending, in-kind and non-financial contributions. 
Regarding verification, each political party is obligated to instruct an accountant to examine their financial reports. Each party that participates in the elections has to provide the Minister of Internal Affairs an overview per calendar year with donations above €4500,- and debts more than €25.000,-. For candidates that are on the list of candidates for the elections the same rules apply: donations, gifts, etc. above €4500,- need to be reported per calendar year.  The Commission 'toezicht financiën politieke partijen' made up by three members provides advice regarding the supervision of this Act. For example, analysing the provision of all the required data by each political party, the designation of a legal entity as an ancillary institution, the possible omission of the data of natural persons for security reasons and the imposition of an administrative fine.

1 - https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0033004/2019-02-23

indicators.justification:
Ministries or regulatory agencies in the Netherlands don't have the legal obligation to set up public consultations and publish the text of proposed regulations before their enactment (1). Even though there are no legal obligations to do so, public consultations are organised frequently by ministries and regulatory agencies to publish proposed regulations, anticipated regulatory changes. This is the result of the position of the Dutch cabinet on internet consultation legislation (2). This position states that the government considers internet consultation a useful instrument as a supplement to the already existing consultation practice in the legislative process.  This cabinet's position from 2011 expresses the wish to continue the consultation experiment and provides certain non-binding conditions and principles for the use of internet consultations:  a minimum duration of a public consultation of 4 weeks, clear and comprehensible explanation of the content of the proposal, the aim and the expected effects for the target groups need to be provided, which issues are up for public consultation and which not, that citizens, companies and institutions are drawn as much as possible to consultations on proposals that may affect them, public reactions to consultations are only made public if the individual or organisations responsible agree to this and that after a decision by cabinet a summary of the results of the consultation are published. In practice however the noncommittal character of this position is prominent. For example, the public consultation period regarding controversial proposed legislation that makes it possible for NCTV terrorism coordinator to follow citizens online was only a couple days instead of the suggested 4 weeks (3). To this date this experimentation phase is still ongoing and there do not seem to be any plans to propose binding legislation on public consultation.

(1) https://rulemaking.worldbank.org/en/data/explorecountries/netherland
(2) https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/documenten/kamerstukken/2011/06/17/kabinetsstandpunt-internetconsultatie-wetgeving
(3) https://www.rtlnieuws.nl/tech/artikel/5238742/nctv-wetsvoorstel-privacy-onzorgvuldig-amnesty-kritiek

indicators.justification:
To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on the performance of right to information (RTI) / freedom of information (FOI) processes?

Under the Wet openbaarheid van bestuur (Wob) (1), anyone can request administrative bodies to disclose documents. The Wob outlines how a Freedom of Information request should be handled, as well as which information can and cannot be disclosed. This Act is broad in scope: it applies to all levels of government, administrative authorities whose activities are subject to the responsibility of the authorities, state owned enterprises and all materials held by or on behalf of public authorities (2). Although it overrides all other laws regarding access to information, there are grounds for not granting access or refraining from the publication of certain information. Information is not provided if disclosure leads to disproportionate advantage or disadvantage to the natural or legal persons concerned or to third parties. Or where a request concerns information that is drafted for the purpose of internal consultation, no information is  disclosed concerning personal opinions of the civil servants involved. There is no harm test to test the grounds of non disclosure except for matters regarding the Unity of the Crown and Security of the State and the public interest override mechanism only related to certain issues.  
In relation to the publication of documents that are required to become publicly available the  Act states that the information only should be provided to the person who has requested the information. Public authorities are not required to create and update lists or registers of the documents in their possession, and to make these public. Also no other legal mechanisms to publish this data on a certain website or platform are in place (2). 

(1) https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0005252/2018-07-28
(2) https://www.rti-rating.org/country-detail/?country=Netherlands

indicators.justification:
There are a lot of Dutch companies that use Company information to provide KYC services: 'Know Your Customer/Client'.  Some use open data sets, some buy Trade Register data in bulk. DR3Data, Company.info, Graydon, Altares Dun & Bradstreet, Creditsafe and other KYC-companies and data brokers analyse this data and provide company profiles that combine (open) datasets on company information. They provide insight into the identity, suitability and risks of business relationships, to protect companies and help them grow through targeted sales and marketing.  A google search for KYC services in the Netherlands provides a long list of companies that offer these services and products. The above-mentioned companies are part of a branch organization called VVZBI: the Association for Corporate B2B Information. 

Also, the Chamber of Commerce (KvK), an independant, commercial government body that manages the Trade Register, offers the KvK Dataservice for a monthly plus pay-per-use fee through which the software, databases and systems of companies can be connected to the Trade Register, so they always have 'the most recent information' at their disposal, 'straight from the source'. According to the KvK, this is the best way to stay in the loop about who they are doing business with. (1) Therefore, the KvK is trying to restrict the use of Company Register information by the companies mentioned above, for instance through the Terms of Use that apply to Trade Register information. (2)  However, currently there is a court case going on against the KVK for applying these Terms of Use. Database law and the Trade Register Act, provide the KVK with ownership and control over what happens with the data.  From internal documents acquired through an FOI-request, it appears that the KVK is taking a commercial approach. It tries to position themselves as a KYC stakeholder, limiting certain companies to provide similar services through the Terms of Use. So KYC and due diligence companies, through the VVZBI, have taken the KVK to court for excluding them from the KvK's dataservice, monopolising company data and its use. They claim the KvK cannot invoke the database rights, since the database was created as part of the KvK's fulfillment of its public task.(3) In Dutch media there is a lot of critique on the KvK's financial model and the way they are expanding their service. 

According to the KvK, by far most of the data from the Trade Register is used for public service: all governments, like municipalities, provinces and water boards use the data in the performance of their duties. (4) For instance when they grant permits or collect taxes. In 2015 the ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate has decided that by january 2021 at the latest, all governing bodies should be connected to the Trade Register and that they have to use it when, in the performance of their duties, they need information about a company or legal entity. This was laid down in article 30 of the Hrw 2007. (5) Also, governments use due diligence tools or services provided by private companies. Graydon for instance, works with national, provincial and regional governments in public-private partnerships, helping them solve problems through data insights. (6)

Civil society also uses company information provided by the KvK, and in databases of private due diligence companies. Their reports and research into their members is based on the databases and information products these companies provide. For instance, SOMO, a critical, independent non-profit foundation that investigates multinationals and the impact of their activities on people and the environment, uses company profiles provided by the KvK, but also international financial data bases (like Thomson Reuters) and local ones. (7) Also, labor associations such as FNV use the services provided by the KvK and due diligence companies.  

Also, different private sectors make use of KYC-companies and the KvK Dataservice. For instance, Company.info works with ABN Amro (bank), GreenChoice (renewable energy), Athlon (car leasing), Talent Peaks (recruitment agency), Knab (online bank). (8) Altares Dun & Bradstreet's database is used by more than 100.000 organizations. (9) And Graydon, who works with companies in the financial sector, in construction, and in the 'flex-market'. (10) 

The media uses company data as well, mostly directly from the KvK Trade Register and UBO-register.  Investigative journalism platforms, like  Follow the Money and The Correspondent, use it to expose shady public-private deals, misuse of public support measures, fraud, et cetera.  (11) (12) (13) Also, newspapers use company data. For example,  the NRC built a database to find out how many company directors are female.  (14) We do not know for sure whether media companies ever use private KYC-companies or data brokers. 

It is impossible to determine the precise magnitude of the impact of company information use. The examples above show a positive impact: the media uses UBO and company data to expose shady deals and fraud, and all big companies and banks seem to need the services of KYC and due diligence to grow and protect their businesses. However, as all the question in this indicator have shown, company information in the Netherlands is still very much closed off. It is publicly available, but only through registration and payment, and almost none of it comes in machine-readable, reusable formats. That is why a lot of potential value is still lost. For example, small start up companies and independent journalists may not be able to access the data because they cannot afford to pay for it. That is why a lot of potential innovation and economic growth is wasted and why more fraud, tax evasion and corruption then necessary go undiscovered. (15) 

(1) KVK, 'KVK Dataservice', https://www.kvk.nl/producten-bestellen/handelsregister-dataservice/. 
(2) KVK, 'Gebruikersvoorwaarden', https://www.kvk.nl/over-kvk/over-het-handelsregister/toegang-handelsregister/aanvraag-toegangscode/gebruiksvoorwaarden/. 
(3) Driessen, 'De strijd tussen de KvK en vijf grote data-afnemers', 25 januari 2021, https://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2021/01/25/de-strijd-om-bedrijfsdata-is-nog-lang-niet-ten-einde-a4029127. 
(4) KvK, 'Waarvoor gebruiken we je persoonsgegevens?', https://www.kvk.nl/privacy/privacyverklaring/waarvoor-gebruiken-we-je-persoonsgegevens/. 
(5) KvK, 'KvK Dataservice: digitaal aansluiten op het Handelsregister voor bestuursorganen' , https://www.kvk.nl/informatiebank/aansluiten-overheid-op-het-handelsregister/, and Handelsregisterwet 2007, Chapter 5: Verstrekking van gegevens aan bestuursorganen en andere bevoegde autoriteiten en gebruik van gegevens door bestuursorganen, Section 5.2: Gebruik door bestuursorganen, Article 30, https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0021777/2021-07-01. 
(6) Graydon, 'Publieke sector', https://www.graydon.nl/nl/waarom-graydon/industry-insights/publieke-sector. 
(7) SOMO, 'Onderzoek op maat', https://www.somo.nl/nl/diensten/onze-diensten/onderzoek-op-maat/ and as an example of research, see the sources used in Romgens & Kiezebrink, 'Grote bedrijven, kleine lasten', 2016, p. 93, https://www.somo.nl/nl/grote-bedrijven-kleine-lasten-3/. 
(8) Company.info, https://companyinfo.nl/. 
(9) Altares Dun & Bradstreet's, https://www.altares.nl/. 
(10) Graydon, https://www.graydon.nl/nl. 
(11) Strop & Vermeuelen, 'Sywert van Lienden sluisde 9 miljoen euro naar persoonlijke holding', Follow the Money, May 31st 2021, https://www.ftm.nl/artikelen/sywert-van-lienden-sluisde-9-miljoen-euro-naar-persoonlijke-holding?share=LeFhVXLQF%2FkhzNpL61q5E2LUa%2FdqznzXo0TESucnaH%2BVk8xm8aRtWC7dcfLhWpY%3D. 
(12) Koster & Koens, 'Hoe arbeidsmigranten werden misbruikt bij de aanvraag van NOW-subsidies', Follow the Money, June 19th 2021, https://www.ftm.nl/artikelen/misbruik-arbeidsmigranten-door-uitzendbureaus-bij-aanvraag-now-subsidies?share=PlaBBU4j%2FdjnDRykbZBoEQGwkaVjgfpXjeG6kLXIMDQ5%2FPLOLShR%2BQkU8UEe5K0%3D. 
(13) Wittenberg, 'Hoe bij PostNL de wet wordt ontdoken om lonen te drukken', 5 december 2017, https://decorrespondent.nl/7681/hoe-bij-postnl-de-wet-wordt-ontdoken-om-lonen-te-drukken/3501049595923-e3a44620. 
(14) Sterk, Tamminga & Molijn, 'Meer vrouwen in de top? Dat lukt alleen de bedrijven die ertoe verplicht worden', April 23th 2021, https://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2021/04/23/meer-vrouwen-in-de-top-dat-lukt-alleen-de-bedrijven-die-ertoe-verplicht-worden-a4041062. 
(15) Open State Foundation, 'Inbreng Open State Foundation ten behoeve van rondetafelgesprek Handelsregisterwet' [Position paper sent to the House of Representatives], April 5th 2019, https://app.1848.nl/document/overig_kamerstuk/23295.

indicators.justification:
Land tenure and use has become an important subject, because of scarce land space and housing shortages. However, the data supplied by registries the Land Registry (Kadaster) and the Basic Registry Topography, do not seem to be utilised often by private sectors, civil society organisations and academics. Presumably because the problem of  housing shortages is mapped out through demographic statistics data, and because in the Netherlands there are not many problems relating to land use and for instance the environment. There is however some evidence of interesting research by the media, and the first one does concern a topic that could incite policy change: in August 2019 newspaper Trouw published an article about land use: 'Holland continues to urbanise at the expense of farmers'. They used figures on farm land and data analysis about land use from the independent government organisation Statistics Netherlands (CBS), too conclude that in twenty years, almost 60.000 extra acres of land have been deployed for living, working and infrastructure, but that also 9.000 acres have been given back to nature (between 2012 and 2015. (1) 

Furthermore, in September 2020 newspaper Trouw published an article: 'Almost no Dutch woman owns land. How strange is that?'. It was an interview with a professor from Oxford, Linda Scott, who researches womens' economic position. (2) And newspaper The Volkskrant published an article in November 2020, called 'Who owns the land in the Netherlands?'. They wrote: 'Space for houses, recreation, windmills or food cultivation is becoming scarcer. So the question arises who owns the land in the Netherlands and who can determine what happens to that land.' At the request of the Volkskrant, the Land Registry had compiled a list of the three hundred largest landowners in the Netherlands, how much land they own and which part of it they use. The paper discovered that the State and other government bodies together own two thirds of the total land of these 300 owners. (3) 

There is also some evidence from land data being used by researchers. For example, the researcher Linda Scott mentioned above, researched the amount of Dutch women that own land, to conclude there is severe inequality due to a 'shocking male monopoly of money and power', while land is the most important source of human wealth. Also, the Trouw article mentioned above about urbanisation at the expense of farmland, is based on data analysis by Statistics Netherlands (CBS) and mentions research from Wageningen University, in which predictive calculation were made about how much farmland will be lost in The Flevopolder between 2025 and 2040. In the research report, the future land use in the province of Flevoland is outlined based on: the current land use situation; current and expected developments which influence the size and use of the current agricultural area, and opportunities and obstacles in land use for the sub areas where these developments (may) take place. Also, it provides advice on the strategy to be followed in dealing with the developments mentioned and concludes with recommendations. (4) Also, there is some evidence suggesting that this research report may lead to policy change. It was presented to State Secretary Knops of the Ministry of Interior and Kingdom Relations, who said he supported the initiative to try out new combinations of land use. Knops is prepared to make government land available for this purpose. This in line with his policy of using government land for innovative and multiple land use and thus for social benefit. (5) 

Furthermore, there is The Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency, which researched global land use, for instance in the context of sustainability. They contribute to reports at global an European level. (6) There is no evidence of other recent research focussed on the Netherlands. Lastly, the Cadastre has a 'datalabs': an initiative that consists of linked data 'stories', in which they combine the data from different registries that they manage (like land use and tenure), with other datasets, in order to show the potential value of their. An example: they linked the statistics on the amount of occupied ICU beds, which the National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM) offers as part of their CoronaWatchNL-project, to the land use data from the Basis Registry Topography, which includes building types, to find out where the closest vacant hotel building is in the vicinity of each hospital. This could solve capacity problems when these hospitals fill up. The vacancy status of these building is obtained by linking the land use data to data from the Basic Registration Addresses and buildings, which contains the status of each building. (7) The Kadaster is just experimenting with this project (and others) to show potential value, so they are trying to affect policy change with them. 

(1) Van Velzen, 'Nederland verstedelijkt en dat gaat ten koste van de boeren', Trouw, 27 augustus, https://www.trouw.nl/nieuws/nederland-verstedelijkt-verder-en-dat-gaat-ten-koste-van-de-boeren~b6e018e7/.

(4) Vogelzang, Smit, Kuiper, Paul & Gillet, '​​Grond in beweging : ontwikkelingen in het grondgebruik in de provincie Flevoland in de periode tot 2025 en 2040', Wageningen University and Research, 2019 (file attached).
(5) Rijksvastgoedbedrijf, 'Staatssecretaris Knops bij ontvangst rapport 'Grond in Beweging': innovatief grondgebruik steunen', 8 maart 2019, https://www.rijksvastgoedbedrijf.nl/actueel/nieuws/2019/03/08/staatssecretaris-knops-bij-ontvangst-rapport-%E2%80%98grond-in-beweging%E2%80%99-innovatief-grondgebruik-steunen. 
(6) Bringezu et al., 'Assessing gland use: balancing consumption with global supply', UN Environment Programme (file attached). 
(7) Kadaster Labs, 'COVID-19 statistieken voor Nederland', https://labs.kadaster.nl/stories/covid-19/. And for other examples of data stories: https://labs.kadaster.nl/stories/.

indicators.justification:
Even though political integrity data in the Netherlands is far from comprehensive and accurate, dutch civil society stakeholders are capable of identifying, exposing and/or highlighting political integrity issues by using the data available at hand or getting access to data through Wob e.g. FOI requests. 
Integrity Watch is an initiative of Transparency International Netherlands that monitors ancillary incomes, gifts received and the number of trips made by members of parliament (1), investigative journalists organisations such as Zembla and Follow the Money have provided critical insights into issues such as shady political party finance (2) and (structurally) not reported ancillary incomes of certain members of parliament (3). Public consultations are frequently used by branche organisations, NGOs, universities to provide input or critical feedback on proposed legislation. For example the case of DeGoedeZaak raising awareness in regard to legislation not being passed through parliament regarding protecting personal data of freelancers that are registered in the dutch Company Register and the fact that the Chamber of Commerce is selling this data (4).
The published information regarding public finance is used to shine light on underfunding of municipalities in the health and social domain and consequential incapacity to effectively organise public service in these domains (5). Regarding public procurement many publications have highlighted shady and questionable deals with the provision of facemasks (6) or awarding a contract of approximately €1 billion to one organisation for setting up COVID-19 testing events  without following public procurement procedures and any oversight and control on how these public funds are spend (7). 

(1) https://www.integritywatch.nl/
(2) https://www.ftm.nl/dossier/de-financiering-van-onze-politieke-partijen
(3)https://www.bnnvara.nl/zembla/artikelen/tientallen-politici-in-de-fout-met-nevenfuncties
(4) https://actie.degoedezaak.org/petitions/verkoop-ons-niet
(5) https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/documenten/rapporten/2021/06/17/onderzoek-naar-mogelijke-onregelmatigheden-in-relatie-tot-het-landelijk-consortium-hulpmiddelen-relief-goods-alliance
(6) https://www.volkskrant.nl/nieuws-achtergrond/het-is-te-duur-en-slecht-georganiseerd-waar-komt-de-kritiek-op-toegangstesten-vandaan~b66e3d9c/
(7) https://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2021/04/16/geharrewar-over-testen-en-11-mld-a4040189

indicators.justification:
In the Netherlands the public procurement data that is available is primarily used by (social) business and enterprises that aim to participate in public tenders or procurement opportunities. Various dashboards and visualization tools are available and developed by companies. Either commercially (example see (1) or as freely available (2).

There are also certain tools that help governments with monitoring and evaluating social, sustainable and environmental procurement. An example is the 'MVI-Zelfevaluatie tool' (3). This tool provides procuring agencies insights into their performance in regard to socially, environmental and sustainable responsible procurement. 

Unfortunately, due to the lack of information available publicly regarding the contracts, payments, service delivery, etc. as described in the previous section, civil society actors such as journalists, public watchdogs, researchers are having difficulty in contributing to the integrity, effectiveness and efficiency of public procurement. Red flagging public procurements is hard due to the lack of data, monitoring service delivery is impossible. Still these types of organisations are identifying, highlighting issues regarding public procurements. The data that is available is used or either (additional) information is requested and accessed via Wob/FOI requests (4).

(1)https://significant-nieuws.nl/2018/06/14/tenderdashboard-significant/
(2) https://ignity.com/dataset/inkoopdata-rijksoverheid/
(3) https://www.pianoo.nl/nl/themas/maatschappelijk-verantwoord-inkopen/praktijk-tools/mvi-criteriatool
(4) https://openstate.eu/nl/2021/05/open-inkoop-in-beeld-presentatie-van-eindrapport-eerste-fase/
